Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: AUSTRALIAN ECONOMY
text: I refer the Prime Minister to his wartime invocations and the generally alarming picture he now paints about the state of the Australian economy. I ask the honourable gentleman: Why was the Government's detailed submission to the 1986 national wage case virtually silent on the terms of trade crisis? Why did the Treasurer's major address to the Economic Planning Advisory Council in May express no concern about our terms of trade? Why did the Treasurer say only three months ago that the Australian economy was entirely robust and entirely healthy despite the then record high interest rates, very high inflation and major balance of payments troubles? Is the Prime Minister willing to offer the Australian public some apology and explanation for the appalling deception that he and his colleagues have practised for at least the past 12 months?

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: AUSTRALIAN ECONOMY
text: I welcome the question from the Leader of the Opposition. I assert that, in respect of the submissions to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and the other occasions encompassed in the honour the able gentleman's question, the Government and the Treasurer properly and with responsibility made the position of the Government quite clear. I am indebted to the Leader of the Opposition for giving me at the outset of the resumption of this session of the Parliament the opportunity to contrast the responsible position of this Government with that of the Opposition. Opposition members-Ha, hal

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: AUSTRALIAN ECONOMY
text: Honourable members opposite may laugh but they will not laugh when I have finished. This Government has a proper concern for the welfare of this community and does not seek in any way to obtain political advantage from the economic misfortune that has visited upon this country. I contrast that attitude of this Government with the position of the Opposition, including particularly the Leader of the Opposition and other members of his party. I refer simply to two examples of the total irresponsibility of the Liberal Party in this country. I refer first of all to the now infamous interview with the Leader of the Opposition in the Australian Financial Review in which he said: 'The times will suit me'. He looked at the deteriorating economic situation, and his words were: 'The times will suit me'. He looks with eagerness to a deteriorating economic situation imposed upon his fellow countrymen by external circumstances. Perhaps the position of the Liberal Party, which the honourable gentleman leads, is best encapsulated by a letter which I wish to read to the House from a member of the Liberal Party, the honourable gentleman's Party, in Western Australia. I do not believe that members of the Australian community will be able to believe the truth of this, but I want it read fully into the record of this House so that the people of Australia will understand just where the Liberal Party puts the interests of this country. This letter was written by Mr Lightfoot, a Liberal member of the Western Australian Parliament, to George Shultz, the United States Secretary of State. He wrote: Dear Sir, May I urge you to stand fast on the proposed wheat sales to China and Russia. Your actions will have a detrimental trade effect on the two socialist Governments of my nation and New Zealand that those respective Administrations would have difficulty recovering from. He was saying that the United States should impose the greatest burden that it possibly can on the people of Australia. He went on: Were you to capitulate now, the effect would be twofold. It gets rather interesting now. The letter continues: Firstly, you will enhance the tarnished image of our Prime Minister Hawke and restore his previously held omnipotence, and that would not be in the interests of free peoples in this hemisphere. Hawke would be written up in the Australian media as the man who coerced you and your president into changing your mind-and that leads into the second effect-it would further entrench the socialist system and may deny the conservative parties the right to govern in 1988-89 because of the arresting of the decline in the Australian dollar and the easing of our balance of payments. No doubt you have already considered the hypothesis here to before outlined. Your decision now, not to go ahead with the sales, would have profound effects on our forming a Government-at the next election. I therefore again urge you to stand fast on your decision. If there has ever been a more treacherous action and treasonable action by a political party in the history of this country I would like to hear it. Here is the Liberal Party deliberately asking the United States Administration to visit upon the farmers of this country a continuing burden, knowing that that will not only adversely affect the rural community of this country but also impose burdens upon the whole of Australia. So that it may enhance its chances of governing in a later period, here is the Liberal Party saying to the United States: 'Punish Australia now, and punish it next year so that that increases our chances of governing'. I compare with pride the responsible attitudes of this Government and of our spokespersons with the miserable and treacherous attitude of the Opposition. NA NA NA

Speaker: Ms FATIN
Title: ORGANISATION
text: Is the Minister for Science aware that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation is seriously underrepresented in Western Australia? Is he aware of the concerns that are being expressed in Western Australia that the existing division of ground water research will be transferred from Perth to Canberra? Can he give the House and the Western Australian Government any assurances on this matter?

Speaker: Mr BARRY JONES
Title: ORGANISATION
text: The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation has recently reorganised its water resources research through the formation of a CSIRO Division of Water Resources Research. Western Australian Ministers, particularly the Premier and the Deputy Premier, the West Australian Advisory Committee of the CSIRO and the West Australian-based CSIRO staff have made strong representations for the headquarters of the Division to be located in Perth. Canberra based staff, honourable members will be amazed to learn, have called for the headquarters to be located in the Australian Capital Territory. We are well aware that there is a serious historic under-representation of the CSIRO in Western Australia. The new Division of Water Resources Research will comprise the old Division of Groundwater Research in Perth, the Division of Water and Land Resources in Canberra and the hydrology group of the Division of Soils in Adelaide. About 200 staff are involved in the reorganisation and the Division will be responsible for developing CSIROs role in the nation's water resources research. Incidentally bringing it all together is a cause that the honourable member for Hawker has proposed for many years. Unfortunately, the honourable member is not with us this afternoon, but this move is a striking endorsement of something that he has wanted for so long. The new Division will deal with the maintenance of the quality and quantity of water supplies and the disposal of waste water. It will also work on projects of major national importance with substantial agency or user support. A world wide search for a chief of the new Division is under way and the Division will be established when the chief takes up his perch. I am glad the honourable member for Hawker is now with us. I was just saying that the establishment of the new Division of Water Resources Research is a tribute to a cause that he has pushed for a very long time. The bad news is that it will not be in his electorate; it will, in fact, be established in Perth. That is an earnest of our continuing determination to make sure the organisation is well represented in Perth, and I can assure honourable members that the West Australian Government is delighted by the outcome. Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Title: MR JUSTICE MURPHY
text: Will the Attorney-General, as the Minister responsible for the administration of justice, state whether he endorses the return of Mr Justice Murphy to the High Court of Australia? Will he advise the House whether, since the establishment of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry, there have been any changes to the constitutional considerations which led to that establishment and, if so, what they are? Will he inform us of the intentions of Mr Justice Murphy as to sitting on the Court? Will he confirm that it has been the practice of the High Court to sit a bench of seven in cases of public importance, especially constitutional cases, and advise us how this practice can be given effect to as long as the present situation persists?

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Title: MR JUSTICE MURPHY
text: I think it is a matter of regret that the matters that have now been raised by the honourable member should be in the context of there being something improper about Mr Justice Murphy going back to the Bench. I think it is known that the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry has reported that it has medical evidence that Mr Justice Murphy is suffering from a very serious illness. The prognosis shows very clearly that it is indeed a serious one. That Commission saw fit to say that because of that illness and in recognition of it His Honour would not be able to appear before the Commission-

Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Title: MR JUSTICE MURPHY
text: In Sydney?

Speaker: Madam SPEAKER
Title: MR JUSTICE MURPHY
text: Order! The honourable member has asked his question. He will now await the answer.

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Title: MR JUSTICE MURPHY
text: I will give the honourable member the answer. He does not like the answer he is getting because it is the truth. I am telling the honourable member what the Parliamentary Commission has established and he is trying to harangue somebody who is suffering grievously-

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: MR JUSTICE MURPHY
text: We are not haranguing him; we are haranguing you.

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Title: MR JUSTICE MURPHY
text: Yes, you are. The honourable member should not point his finger at me, either. It would have been better if he had kept quiet from the point of view of what we are about in this context. Let us make it very clear indeed that Mr Justice Murphy voluntarily refrained from sitting on the Court.

Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Title: MR JUSTICE MURPHY
text: Which we all endorsed.

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Title: MR JUSTICE MURPHY
text: Very belatedly. Let us make it very clear that when Mr Justice Murphy was acquitted the honourable member, to his credit, was the first to issue a Press statement saying well, of course, they would not pursue the Murphy matter any further.

Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Title: MR JUSTICE MURPHY
text: That is not the position.

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Title: MR JUSTICE MURPHY
text: It is the position. The honourable member issued a Press statement on that basis. As a result of some discussions, to which I was not privy, that Mr Justice Murphy had with his colleagues on the High Court, they decided that he would agree to refrain from sitting so that he could give them some explanation. Subsequent to that, surprisingly for us as a government, the justices of the High Court issued a further Press statement saying that they did not really want to discuss that matter. They had discussed it, but they were not discussing it as a court. They merely wanted to know what might be Mr Justice Murphy's explanation. In recent days, I have had the benefit of talking to Mr Justice Murphy and he makes it very clear-

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: MR JUSTICE MURPHY
text: Has he given you any information?

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Title: MR JUSTICE MURPHY
text: I think that he is a very sick person. He makes it very clear that in the discussions he had with his fellow judges there was never any suggestion that he should not sit with them. That is of some surprise to me, in view of other information given to me at the time. This is the important part. There we have the justices of the High Court not objecting to sitting with their brother judge. It was understandable then that he was certainly of such a mind. In view of the fact that he had received this dreadful diagnosis and that he has to think of the welfare of his family and his children and what they might think of their father, what was wrong with the man exercising his discretion to go back to the Bench from which there was no need for him to withdraw? What is wrong with that? The point that we want to emphasise todayI understand, Madam Speaker, that you have some matter to table later-is that we shall be introducing legislation tomorrow to terminate the Commission for reasons that relate directly to the illness and the advice of the Commission itself that it would be impossible to continue. Mr Justice Murphy is now considering six or seven reserve judgments in which he is obliged, naturally, to give his decision. On that basis, I understand that he is now seeking sick leave. That is a matter for the Court itself. In that process of time, it was thought that he would have sufficient time to complete those reserve judgments. Regrettably, it appears that because of the diagnosis and the nature of the illness, he is weakening and therefore may, not be able to resume sittings. I think when the medical evidence has been tabled, as it may, it will be conclusive as to that point. I would only hope, from the point of view of an ordinary human being and a fellow Australian, that there is a remission of his illness. I would hope that there is a chance that his health can be restored and that he can regain his position on the Court. He would then be able to meet any of the accusers that he may have, including those in the Opposition. TOURISTS' VISAS

Speaker: Mr BEDDALL
Title: MR JUSTICE MURPHY
text: Has the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs noted agitation on the part of tourist interests for the provision of visa-free entry to Australia, particularly for holidays, and have there been any developments in this regard?

Speaker: Mr HURFORD
Title: MR JUSTICE MURPHY
text: I have noted that agitation. Given the interest in the visa-free concept, particularly in the tourist industry, the Government has initiated a comprehensive assessment of the costs and benefits of the visa-free arrangement in the Australian context. I point out to the House that just because other countries find visa-free arrangements satisfactory does not mean that they will suit this country; we are in a unique situation in a number of ways. The whole issue is very complex. Further work has been done on this issue since the House last met. That work has addressed itself to the fact that visas do keep undesirable people out of this country, which is a very popular country for people to visit. For a start, over one million people want to come here every year for permanent residency and less than 100,000 places are available. This puts us in a very different situation from, for instance, Japan; there is no desire to any great extent on the part of people from outside Japan for permanent residence there. However, we will look at ways in which we can facilitate the tourist industry. But I ask the House to consider-I will be very pleased to receive any representation that any honourable member wishes to put to me on this issue-the fact that, if and when we do allow any visa-free arrangements of, say, a short term duration for tourists, we will have to be selective. We will have to select countries from which we do not take many permanent residents, countries from which there is not much demand for permanent residence. This will be tough and hard decisions will have to be taken as to the countries we will choose. I thank the honourable member for Rankin for allowing me to bring the House up to date on this matter. However, we will continue to give good service where visas are necessary, which is from everywhere but New Zealand. We aim to give a 48-hour turnaround service. We will look at helping the tourist industry by selectively allowing visa-free arrangements if these are at all possible. NA

Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Title: MR JUSTICE MURPHY
text: My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to his recent statement that the making of exgratia payments for Mr Justice Murphy's legal costs could be justified. I ask him to do that and, in so doing, to state the amounts involved and the precise facts and special circumstances said to justify the payments. He should state how the position of Mr Justice Murphy in respect of costs of the court proceedings-I emphasise the word 'court'-differs from the position of other defendants acquitted on criminal charges. He should state what proportion of the costs are to be borne by Mr Justice Murphy and what are the funds available in the trust fund established to help pay his costs. He should also table all the relevant documents.

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: MR JUSTICE MURPHY
text: It is fascinating to note on the resumption of this Parliament that the Opposition is not only treacherous to the economic interest of this country but also totally lacking in any semblance of decency and good taste. Nevertheless, I will respond to the second question in this area that has been pressed by the Opposition. There are two separate issues relating to the costs incurred by Mr Justice Murphy. That will probably be clear to most members of the House. The first concerns his costs arising out of the conduct of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry established by this Parliament. The second relates to his costs in defending criminal prosecutions. As to the first, in accordance with the provisions of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Act, the Attorney-General has authorised the payment of the Judge's costs relating to the operation of the Commission. He did so following a request from the President and from yourself, Madam Speaker, on 2 June that these costs be met. Under the Act the Attorney-General is required to comply with that request. As yet no accounts have been received. As to the second, the costs of defending the criminal prosecution matters, the Acting Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, said on 1 August, in announcing the Government's decision: . . . the decision of the to initiate proceedings here was expressly made on the basis of special considerations said to be applicable to holders of public office. I conclude by saying that the Government has not yet looked in detail at this matter and has not decided at this stage what the appropriate payment will be. As far as the Government is concerned, that is all that will be said on this matter at this stage. NA

Speaker: Mr MAHER
Title: PHARMACEUTICAL BENEFITS
text: My question is directed to the Minister for Health. Why does the Government intend to delete certain analgesics and 45 other preparations from the list of 2,500 pharmaceutical benefits now available on prescription free of charge to pensioners?

Speaker: Dr BLEWETT
Title: PHARMACEUTICAL BENEFITS
text: There are three points to be made: First of all the decision was made on health grounds on the advice of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee which provides recommendations as to which drugs should go on the essential drug list in this country. Its advice in relation to the 46 formulations we are now discussing was that these were not drugs that could be justified on that essential drug list on grounds of their minor therapeutic effect. That is the first point. The second point that needs to be made in relation to this question is that concern has been expressed on both sides of the House and by medical authorities about the increase in the usage of drugs by pensioners in this country. It has been rising in the last three years by close to 20 per cent a year. If we are to provide free essential drugs to pensioners, certainly the lists have to be looked at in relation to inessential drugs. It will not be possible for any government to go on providing free drugs for pensioners unless those drugs are seen as essential drugs. That is another reason for looking at that particular list. Thirdly, the point needs to be made that nearly all of these drugs are drugs which are obtainable without prescription that is, they are simply across-the-counter drugs which can be bought for $2 and $3 or sometimes from the supermarkets for even less. But the present scheme means that in order for a pensioner to get that drug free he has to go to a doctor and get a consultation at a cost to the taxpayer of some $13. If the drug is then on prescription an extra $2.40 has to be paid as a dispensing fee to the pharmacist. So the taxpayer finishes up paying $16 or $17 for drugs available across the counter for $2 or $3 . Director of Public Prosecutions NA

Speaker: Mr CARLTON
Title: AUSTRALIAN DOLLAR
text: Can the Treasurer confirm reports that the Reserve Bank of Australia spent in the order of $1 billion during July in support of the plummeting Australian dollar? If so, is he concerned that continued support of this order would result in a serious erosion in the level of our international reserves, currently around $13 billion?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Title: AUSTRALIAN DOLLAR
text: The Reserve Bank conducts its daily operations in the foreign exchange markets in the main doing, as it says, smoothing and testing in respect of particular transactions. If indeed there is a very large transaction which threatens to destabilise the rate, sometimes such a transaction is balanced off. Over the course of July the bank did spend considerable funds in the foreign exchange market. I do not think the bank or the Government regards that in any way as any long term solution to what is happening in the exchange markets; hence, the importance of tonight's Budget and the importance the Government places on seeing fundamental change in the structure of economic policy. But again the bank is following its normal role, that is, operating in the foreign exchange market as best and when it sees fit in respect of particular events. Over that period the exchange rate fell dramatically on a couple of days and the bank would be doing less than its task in not engaging in the foreign exchange market at that time. Certainly I concur with the import of the honourable gentleman's question. The Government would not regard simply throwing reserves at the rate as a solution to the exchange rate. NA NA

Speaker: Mr STAPLES
Title: INSTITUTIONS
text: I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Education. It relates to the Government's decision to allow full fee overseas students to study in Australian higher education institutions. Does the Government support the establishment of private tertiary institutions, such as the proposed Bond university on the Gold Coast and the proposed development at Yanchep in Western Australia, to market such courses? Will the Government grant the same privilege to Australian students willing to pay a full fee?

Speaker: Mr DA WKINS
Title: INSTITUTIONS
text: There have been a number of proposals, two quite prominent ones, to establish private universities for full fee paying students. The honourable member will be aware that some time ago the Government announced that it had approved the policy to existing tertiary institutions, that is, the ones funded by the Commonwealth, to admit overseas full fee paying students on the basis of fairly strict guidelines which would ensure that the full cost of providing the places for those overseas students would be met by the fees paid to them. The Government has decided not to extend this arrangement to Australians because the basic reason for providing these new arrangements is to provide an opportunity for essentially the export of education services to students from other countries, particularly those in the region. We have been able to identify a substantial market, particularly within the region, in competition with universities in Britain, United States of America and other places. I would expect that over the years we will see a fairly substantial growth in the number of full fee paying students entering Australia to undertake the courses. However, this has to be done with some sensitivity to ensure that there is a minimum of disruption to the ordinary ongoing work of the institutions themselves. In regard to fully private institutions, the Government does not intend to provide any support to these proposals. We are, however, intending to examine these proposals to ensure again that there is no disruption to the general provision of tertiary education services within Australia. There is one other· point I should make, and that is that as part of the policies announced by myself and the Minister for Education in relation to this matter, we have decided to examine, on a case by case basis, any proposals which involve the development of joint facilities between private and public institutions. If there is an intention of a university or college to get together with some private interests to provide these full fee paying courses for overseas students the Government would want to consider it on the basis of the proposals that are put up to us. Title: INSTITUTIONS

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: EMPLOYEES UNION
text: Did Barrie give you this one?  member that, while ever he visits my electorate, I am safe. He can bring some of his sleazy mates with him too. He has a wide variety. Does he want to talk about it some more? My question is directed to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Can the Minister inform the House of the Government's attitude to claims for, among other things, a $60 per week over-award payment and a 36-hour week which are being pursued by the Plumbers and Gasfitters Employees Unio-?

Speaker: Mr WILLIS
Title: EMPLOYEES UNION
text: I am aware of the policy of the Plumbers and Gasfitters Employees Union to pursue a 13-point log of claims which includes, as the honourable member said, claims for a $60 a week increase and a 36-hour week. Needless to say, the Government is totally opposed to this log of claims. In present circumstances it is difficult to imagine a more damaging action by any section of the Australian economy than for a union to pursue wage increases of this kind which are blatantly in breach of the accord and of the national wage fixing principles. I have conveyed the Government's strong opposition to this course of action to the Plumbers and Gasfitters Employees Union which, nevertheless, is apparently determined to pursue this course. I have informed the union that if it proceeds the Government will take every step possible to ensure that it does not succeed because, as I have pointed out to the Union, if it were to succeed its action would certainly result in grave damage to this economy, and there would certainly be adverse effects on the exchange rate and interest rates. There would be a much higher level of unemployment if we were to have a wages blow-out in this area, spreading as it inevitably would to other areas of the building industry and then to the rest of the economy. We are determined to resist this claim, and I point out that building industry employers have a strong obligation also to resist it. I have pointed out to employers today that the government's code of conduct, which was established in the builders Labourers Federation case, will apply in relation to the Plumbers and Gasfitters Employees Union claims. Essentially that code of conduct provides that building employers are bound to adhere to awards, industrial agreements and the national wage fixing principles. If they do not adhere to those matters, the government can take action against them to disqualify them from future government contracts. This tactic was used successfully by us in respect of the BLF and I expect that it would be successful if we needed to use it again. I believe that everything must be done to oppose these claims, which are extremely damaging. I regret greatly that the union has seen fit to go ahead with the claims. I note that it is doing so in isolationthat no other union affiliated with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, or indeed not affiliated, is pursuing this course. I advise the House that we expect that the Plumbers and Gasfitters Employees Union will fail; the trade union movement of this country will demonstrate that it is a sensible organisation which is prepared to act to ensure the recovery of this nation, to get us out of the difficult circumstance we are in presently; and the accord will continue through difficult times to help this economy to get back to strong economic growth. Speaker: Mr MCGAURAN
Title: HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION
text: Will the Attorney-General confirm to the House the Government's intention to abandon the Bill of rights, for the time being at least? Does the government intend SUbmitting the Bill to the Constitutional Commission or any other body for examination and possible recommendation for further action by the Government? Finally, does the Government intend retaining all or most of the present staff of the Human Rights Commission in the new body which will supposedly succeed the Human Rights Commission at the expiration of its term later this year?

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Title: HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION
text: In answer to the honourable gentleman, let me make it very clear that the present Human Rights Commission and its staff were, of course, constituted by the previous Government. I am well aware of the difficulties anybody has in trying to introduce legislation into this House which might encourage better electoral reform in Australia. Of course, it was my hope that the Senate would have been able to deal with the Bill of Rights that was passed by this House last year. In fact, since last year the Senate has debated that Bill for 36t hours, which is the longest debate since Federation, and has got up to clause 3.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION
text: I don't think the Senate likes it.

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Title: HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION
text: The only reason it does not like it is because it might bring about some electoral reform.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION
text: It is a lousy Bill, Lionel.

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Title: HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION
text: It is not the only lousy thing about the place, is it? Seriously, it is a tragedy to think that legislation passed through the House of Representatives has been deliberately delayed in the Senate for reasons that have nothing to do with the content of the Bill, but for the purpose of delaying its introduction. I accept the fact that the Bill would require introduction and certainly some opportunity to allow it to work before public opinion could accept some of the extraordinary interpretations that have been given to it, particularly by the people opposite. I want to make this point: At the present time the Senate has failed to deal with 27 other Bills that have already been passed by this House. One wonders how we will get the Senate to devote its time to what it is supposed to be doing; that is, reviewing legislation as a House of review. It is becoming a House of delay and obstruction. Having said that, the Bill will not be proceeded with. Something will need to be done about the problems we have in terms of obligations under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. Mr MCGauran-Forget it.

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Title: HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION
text: The honourable gentleman says 'forget it'. Of course, it was the Fraser Government that ratified the International Covenant. Honourable members opposite now say 'shame'. Mr HawkeYou can forget them too.

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Title: HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION
text: The honourable gentleman says that we can forget them, too. As we are a signatory to that covenant with 79 other nations and we have a responsibility in the international sphere to monitor the position of human rights in Australia, there will need to be a commission that will deal not only with the monitoring aspects of the Covenant but also with the obligations we have in respect of the International Labour Organisation Convention on equal opportunity and the questions of race discrimination and sex discrimination under existing legislation. There will be a restructuring of the Commission. I have set in motion a task force to look at what sorts of people will be needed to assist that Commission. I accept the view that there will be a need for people who are directly related to those responsibilities and they will be fewer in number than is the case with the present Commission. Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: DUMPING
text: My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industry, follows what the Prime Minister was talking about concerning the outrageous Lightfoot letter. I ask the Minister: Is it true that, if Mr Lightfoot's exhortation to the American Government leads to a continuation of its policies, not only wheat growers but also cotton, sugar, rice and the soya beans-competing lupin growers will be affected? I further ask whether it is important for the salvation of the Australian industry that we maintain a bipartisan approach to the Americans on this issue of dumping. Title: DUMPING
text: Lightfoot and big mouth. I would like to comment on the latter part of the honourable gentleman's question because a recent all-party delegation went to Washington with a truly bipartisal1 if not tripartisan approach and we were all there for Australia. I hope that Mr Lightfoot's comments do not represent a change of view, given the seriousness with which we regarded the Dole amendment to the export-import Bill in the United States Senate and the Daschle Bill itself. The initial States subsidisation proposals-the Dole and Daschle proposals-could have cost Australian wheat growers $470m this year on top of the $1 billion that the United States Farm Act has already been calculated to have cost us. I find it difficult to imagine anything more reprehensible than for people in the Opposition parties to be seriously saying that they want to see this continuation of a detrimental trade effect to enhance the Liberal Party's and their own electoral prospects. Already the Leader of the Opposition has said that he is relying on an economic recession for his political salvation. I would simply like to say that, under this Government, honourable members opposite will get neither a recession nor their salvation. The honourable gentleman also asked a question about crops other than wheat. With respect to cotton and rice, one element of the United States farm program-the target export assistance program rather than the export enhancement program-will have an even more insidious and more devastating effect than some of the other measures under its farm program. With respect to sugar I do not think we can point the finger so much at the United States, even though it subsidises sugar production at US 18c a pound and the world price is US6c a pound. But the main cause of the problem in the sugar industry still remains with the European Economic Community where its degree and level of subsidisation are even more pronounced. Of course, I think we all regard with dismay, and I am sure that the Deputy Leader of the National Party and his colleague the honourable member for Hume regard with dismay, the fact that when we came back we had this fire sale proposition to China of sugar at a little bit over US4c a pound. All these things add up to an immense cost to Australian farmers and, as this Government has been trying to make quite clear, Australia's farm problems are very much a part of Australia's economic problem-that is, the problem with out balance of payments-and that is the reason why we have problems with our dollar. All these things are interdependent. I would have thought that all people in this House, when they are abroad and when they are reflecting on international matters, would speak with one voice rather than utter this damnable reprehensible nonsense. We maintain that the purpose of Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer, and that they should not be closed merely to save money or help Australia Post make a profit. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of Marsfield Post Office. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray. by Mr Ruddock. Petition received. Private Health Care To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Humble Petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully sayeth: That we the undersigned are totally opposed to any taxation change which involves a tax on Health Fund contributions, health charges or benefits; That we are already required to pay a I percent levy to partly finance the Medicare scheme and that we would regard any further taxation of our health insurance arrangements as unfair and unreasonable; That therefore we urge the Government to ensure that there is no taxation on illness and no special taxation on those who seek to insure themselves against the cost of private health care. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray. by Mr Ruddock. Petition received. South West Africa People's Organisation To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This humble petition of citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: S.WA.P.O. is recognised by the United Nations as the sole and authentic representative of the Namibian people. The situation in Namibia is of particular importance to Australians, given Australia's position as a member of the United Nations Council for Namibia, in effect a member of the UN, the government for Namibia in exile and therefore has a legal international entrusted responsibility tq the people of Namibia, responsibilities which it must be prepared to take seriously in order to bring about social justice, freedom and independence for Namibia and genuine peace in that Region. Therefore this humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully requests the Government to urgently initiate the following steps: I. To fund a S.WA.P.O. Office in Australia, such funding to continue until a free Namibia is able to establish an Embassy in Canberra. 2. That all commercial, sporting and cultural ties with the Republic of South Africa be severed forthwith. 3. That all diplomatic ties with Pretoria be severed. 4. To give decent support to S.WA.P.O. agriculture and educational programs. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray. by Mr Saunderson. Petition received. Discrimination against Women To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled: The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That whereas the Commonwealth of Australia ratified with the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women in 1983, the Government of Victoria in passing the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 is in breach of Article 6 of the Convention which says that "States Parties shall take all appropriate measures, including legislation, to suppress all forms of traffic in women and exploitation of prostitution of women". That the Victorian Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 provides legal authority to brothel operators to traffic in and exploit the prostitution of women and to live off the earnings of prostitutes. That whereas the Federal Minister for Health has counselled citizens to shun promiscuity (The Australian 26/1/85) because of the serious and sometimes fatal health hazards, the operations of legalised brothels encourages promiscuity and the spread of diseases, including AIDS. Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government of Australia having ratified the UN Convention on Women remain consistent in its obligations to uphold the Articles of the Convention and request the Victorian Government to immediately repeal the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray. by Mr Saunderson. Petition received. Plant Variety Rights To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government: I. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security. 2. Recognize that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection, storage, and research has been publicly funded. 3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognize that any system giving - property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust. 4. Recognize that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely: (i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm, (ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes, (iii) farmer unrest at seed prices, (iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals, (v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack. 5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray. by Mr Scholes. Petition received. Native Birds: Trapping and Export To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that: I. We oppose the export of Australian fauna and are concerned that some groups and individuals with a vested interest in the bird trade are lobbying to legalise the export of cockatoos and galahs. 2. We oppose trapping birds in the wild for commercial trade in our own country. Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will: I. Maintain our laws which forbid the export of our native birds. 2. Bring pressure to bear on the States to outlaw the trapping of birds in the wild for commercial trade. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray. by Mr Scholes. Petition received. African National Congress and South West African People's Organisation To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That the humble petitioners respectfully believe that the representatives in Australia of the African National Congress of South Africa (ANC) and of the South West African People's Organisation of Namibia(SW APO) should not have to suffer unending financial problems related to the cost of rent, food and clothing, and the maintenance of two small offices run on the most austere basis. Your petitioners therefore pray and urge Australian Government provision of: I. Official recognition of the ANC and SW APO as the legitimate representatives of the people of South Africa and Namibia; 2. Financial support to the offices and representatives of the ANC and SW APO to promote the anti-Apartheid cause in Australia; 3. Additional financial support for the official representatives of the ANC and SW APO to assist the , humanitarian needs of Namibian and South African refugees who are victims of Apartheid; 4. Scholarships for South African and Namibian refugees. These to be provided through the ANC and SW APO education departments. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray. by Mr Scott. Petition received. Cost of Ski Lift Tickets: Snowy Mountains To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the high cost of ski lift tickets imposed during winter by the operators of resorts within the Snowy Mountains of Australia. Your petitioners below believe The Snowy Mountains are an asset for all Australians to enjoy and should be within the financial reach of all and not just the wealthy few. Your petitioners therefore request that the Parliament take action to reduce the cost of ski lift tickets imposed by the operators of resorts within the Snowy Mountains. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray. by Mr Sharp. Petition received. To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia, electors of the Division of Calare shows the proposed gold tax will severely affect the livelihood of numerous people involved in the exploration, mining and service divisions of the gold mining industry in this district. Your petitioners therefore pray that the proposed gold tax not be introduced. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray. by Mr Simmons. Petition received. African National Congress To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that a known terrorist organisation is operating in Australia under the name of African National Congress with quasi diplomatic status and with the support of the Australian Government. Your petitioners therefore request that the Australian Government will take appropriate action to: Withdraw Government support for this organisation; Expel any officials of this terrorist organisation resident in Australia or visiting under visa conditions. by Mr Sinclair. Petition received. Chernobyl Nuclear Disaster To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens'of Australia respectfully showeth: 1. That following the Chernobyl nuclear disaster of 26th April 1986, the Soviet Union has not yet adequately explained to its citizens or those of the Soviet-occupied Baltic States, Ukraine and other areas affected by the radiation fall-out the potential short-term and long-term health hazards and the available modes of prevention or reduction of radiation poisoning. Neither have the appropriate medicines for substitution therapies to minimise bodily accumulation of radioactive elements been adequately provided. 2. That the Soviet Union operates many nuclear power stations without the elementary structural safeguards against radioactive spillage regarded as mandatory in the West. Of particular concern is the safety of the largest Soviet nuclear power station at Ignalina in Soviet occupied Lithuania, of similar design to Chernobyl, which already has a record of operational problems. Radioactive spillage at Ignalina would quickly contaminate the whole of Latvia, Lithuania as well as vast areas of Europe. We request that the Australian Government will, I. Through the World Health Organisation, provide Gold Tax medical aid and broadcast medical information to the victims of radiation exposure following the Chernobyl disaster. 2. Through the United Nations Organisation request the Soviet Union, (a) to close down all nuclear power stations similar to Chernobyl till protective structures are built. (b) permit international inspection of such safety structures. And your Petitioners, as in Duty bound, will ever pray. by Mr Wilson. Petition received. Home Loan Interest Rates To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth: That the current policy pursued by the Hawke Government is causing an intolerable increase in home loan interest rates beyond the capacity of families to pay. That consequently this policy is causing grave hardship throughout Australia and is contributing to social problems and the breakup of the family unit. That unless the Government act urgently the Australian dream of home ownership is fast becoming shattered for many of our citizens. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government makes home loan interest rates tax deductible therefore alleviating the present crippling burden of current high interest rates on home owners and home buyers. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray. by Mr Slipper. Petition received. To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the electorate of Fisher respectfully showeth that: Whereas the present Government of the Commonwealth of Australia has purported to present the title deeds to Ayers Rock in Central Australia, in reality the joint property of the people of the Commonwealth to an Aboriginal Land Council on 26 October 1985. Whereas opinion polls and statements of representative groups, Members of Parliament and respected individuals show clearly that the Commonwealth Government had no mandate from the citizens of the Commonwealth to act in such a disgraceful manner. Whereas the present Government claims to be totally opposed to apartheid (separate development) in South Africa but purported to hand over Ayers Rock to an Aboriginal Council in support of a policy of apartheid (separate development) which has been shown to be detrimental to the Aboriginal people of Australia. Whereas it is pursuing this policy making it a crime for most white and many Aboriginals to enter, without permit, large areas of the Commonwealth designated apartheid (i.e., set aside for separate development), trary to our democratic traditions and experience of freedom of movement for citizens of all racial origins within Australia. Whereas Australian citizens have no present means available to them to prevent this violation of their natural rights to unfettered common ownership of, and access to, a treasured natural asset. Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Seek means available for the protection of the peopie's interests to reverse this outrage aDd preserve the democratic traditions of Australia. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray. by Mr Slipper. Petition received. Fringe Benefits Tax To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher respectfully showeth that: The total disallowance by the Hawke Labor Government of tax deductibility for entertainment and hospitality expenses will unfairly penalise Australian and cost thousands of jobs for young and unskilled people. Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to abandon its total ban on entertainment expenses and allow tax deductibility for legitimate and necessary expenses. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray. by Mr Slipper. Petition received. Ayers Rock Capital Gains Tax To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher respectfully showeth that: The proposed capital gains tax penalises small business, discourages long-term investment, hinders capital formation and will freeze existing investment patterns and limits the investors' ability to adjust to changed market conditions. Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to immediately abandon its ill-considered capital gains tax proposal. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray. by Mr Slipper. Petition received. Superannuation To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Page conelectorate respectfully showeth that: The Hawke Labor government's productivity-superannuation accord with the ACTU and its support of the superannuation claims of the trade union movement will create an imbalance in industrial power and distort the future development of the Australian economy. Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Reject the superannuation claim of the trade union movement, and allow superannuation to develop without trade union domination. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray. by Mr Blunt, Mr Hicks, Mr Nehl and Mr Ian Robinson. Petitions received. Australian Bill of Rights Bill To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that: The Hawke Labor Government's Bill of Rights seeks to make changes in the constitutional balance in Australia by intruding into the affairs of individuals and of business State and local governments. Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of government. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray. by Mr Blunt and Mr Ian Robinson. Petitions received. Australian Bill of Rights Bill the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that: The Hawke Labor Government's Bill of Rights seeks to make changes in the constitutional balance in Australia by intruding into the affairs of individuals and of State and local governments. Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of government. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray. by Mr Hunt. Petition received. Australian Bill of Rights Bill To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth: That the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 will endanger the Federal system of Australia, the State and Federal criminal justice systems, the State and Federal police forces, the State and Federal education systems, the independence of the churches and religious associations, marriage and the family, children, the unborn, the handicapped, the aged and the infirm, employer and employee relationships and Australian society generally. Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Repeal the Bill of Rights legislation forthwith. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray. by Mr Slipper. Petition received. Human Rights Legislation To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain electors of the Division of Cowper respectfully showeth: That the Bill of Rights Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Amendment Bill and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill, if passed by the Parliament, will undermine human and civil rights in Australia, will attack the institution of the family in our country, and will destroy States rights and the federal nature of our Commonwealth. Your petitioners humbly pray that: The Parliament rejects these Bills, abolishes the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and moves to withdraw ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray. by Mr Hunt. Petition received. Human Rights Legislation To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble Petition of certain electors of the Division of Cowper respectfully showeth: That the Bill of Rights Bill, the Human Rights Bill and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Amendment Bill, and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill, if passed by the Parliament, will undermine human and civil rights in Australia, will attack the institution of the family in our country, and will destroy States rights and the federal nature of our Commonwealth. Your Petitioners humbly pray that: The Parliament rejects these Bills, abolishes the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and moves to withdraw ratification of the International Covenant or Civil and Political Rights. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray. by Mr Ian Cameron. Petition received. Fringe Benefits Tax To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned petitioners of the Federal Electorate of Farrer, do respectfully show our opposition to the introduction of a Fringe Benefits Tax and a Capital Gains Tax, and related legislation. Your petitioners do humbly pray for the repeal of both these pieces of legislation. Such taxes are an additional burden upon Small Business, and lead to increased bureaucracy. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray. by Mr Tim Fischer and Mr Katter. Petitions received. Northern Rivers College of Advanced Education To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that: There is an urgent need to upgrade and extend the facilities at the Northern Rivers College of Advanced Education. Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Provide the necessary capital funding for the Northern Rivers CAE to ensure North Coast students have access to a tertiary institution capable of providing them with the skills they will need to meet the challenges of the future. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray. by Mr Blunt. Petition received. Nuclear Disarmament To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully requests that: The world's resources be redirected to the relief of human suffering, starvation, poverty and disease. Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Stop spending taxpayers' money on self promotion through high cost high profile but superficial policy on nuclear disarmament and make a genuine bi-partisan commitment to positive and practical policies designed to achieve progressive world-wide nuclear disarmament. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray. by Mr Blunt. Petition received. Australian Bill of Rights Bill To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of certain electors of Dawson shows that the proposed Bill of Rights Overlooks basic rights concerning union membership, education and private property, is a basis for massive intrusion into State responsibilities, establishes a Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission with powers similar to a Court but without accepted legal procedures and protections for the accused, and provides no avenue of appeal against decisions of the HR&EOC. The petition further shows that fundamental protection of human rights is already to be found in the Courts, in tolerance, in fair play, belief in democratic institutions and in support for rule of law. Your petitioners humbly pray that the Parliament will not allow the Australian Bill of Rights Bill to pass into law. by Mr Braithwaite. Petition received. Public Park, Nudgee, Queensland To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of certain electors of the division of Lilley shows that there is an area of Commonwealth land surplus to the re-development of the Brisbane Airport site. Your petitioners therefore pray that the Federal Government give favourable consideration to entering into negotiations with the Brisbane City Council in order to provide parkland for the people of Nudgee and surrounding areas. We believe that the nearby residential area is deficient in parkland due to its development prior to the time when provision of parkland by the City Council became a condition of approval for the sub-division of land. Further development of adjoining areas following the opening of the new airport and Gateway Bridge can only make the situation worse. The land to which we refer is situated at the end of Buchanan Road, Nudgee, Queensland, and we believe that part of it would be ideal for use as parkland. by Mrs Darling. Petition received. Fringe Benefits Tax To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives: The humble petition of citizens in the electorate of the Northern Territory respectfully showeth that the proposed introduction of fringe benefits tax in Australia will destroy the future economic growth of the Northern Territory. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia take special consideration of the economic growth of the Northern Territory and completely exempt the Northern Territory from the proposed fringe benefits. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray. by Mr Everingham. Petition received. Western Sydney State University To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth: That they strongly support the establishment of the' Western Sydney State University as recommended in the Parry Report and call upon the House to establish the Western Sydney State University in conjunction with the New South Wales Government. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray. by Mr Free. Petition received. Coptic Orthodox Church To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned members of the Coptic community resident in New South Wales respectfully showeth: Whereas the Coptic Orthodox Church, Diocese of Australia, Parish of New South Wales has enjoyed funding under the Grant-In-Aid Scheme since 1980, and has used the funds granted to employ a full-time social worker to assist members of the Coptic community in Sydney in dealing with problems encountered particularly by ethnic minorities in our society. Whereas the problems of the Coptic community in Sydney are, if anything, greater today than they were in 1980. Whereas the Church's application for continued funding under the Grant-In-Aid Scheme for 1985-86 has been rejected by the Honourable the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Whereas the resultant loss of the services of a full time social worker will cause immense hardship and distress within the Coptic community in Sydney. Your petitioners therefore pray that the funding of the Coptic Orthodox Church, Diocese of Australia and Parish of New South Wales under the Grant-In-Aid Scheme be restored for 1985-86, and for so long thereafter as may be necessary in order to meet the needs of the Coptic community in Sydney. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray. by Ms HcHugh. Petition received. To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of certain citizens of Queensland, Australia, respectfully showeth that we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953). Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change the Australian National Flag. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray. by Mr Millar. Petition received. Pensioners: Telephone Rental and Installation To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: Dear Sir, The Members of the Castlemaine Branch of the Combined Pensioners Association of Victoria humbly petition you to have Rental and Installation Charges for Telephone abolished for Pensioners. It is a heavy burden to Pensioners and with the profit Telecom are making we feel that this is not too much to ask. Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that Rental and Installation charges for pensioners will be abolished. And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray. by Mr O'Keefe. Petition received. Child Care Facilities To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of certain electors of the Division of Kooyong, draws to the attention of the House the lack of full day child care services in the City of Kew compared to the cities of Hawthorn, Sandringham and Mordiallic. Your petitioners therefore ask that our request for finance to establish these facilities through the Department of Community Services, be brought to the attention of Senator Grimes on behalf of the following citizens of the City of Kew.  Petition received. Trade Unions To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Pine Rivers Shire in Queensland respectfully showeth: That the actions of trade unions have gone beyond their traditional goals of protecting workers' conditions National Flag and rates of pay and have reached the point where they are seriously affecting the economic health of the nation and the people. Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray: I. That all Governments throughout Australia acknowledge and protect the Right of Work on behalf of all Australians. 2. That the total sovereignty of individual governments be recognised as a fundamental requirement of a workable, balanced Federal system of government. 3. That all necessary steps be taken to protect the citizens of Australia from any inducement, compulsion, threat or intimidation to join any trade union. 4. That there should be no preference in employment for people who are members of trade unions. 5. That the supremacy of elected governments over Charges the sectional interests of trade unions be recognised, and 6. That the provision of essential services be maintained, free from industrial disruption. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray. by Mr Slipper. Petition received. Speaker: Madam SPEAKER
Title: ECONOMIC CRISIS
text: I have received a letter from the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely: The tragically unnecessary state of economic crisis resulting from the Hawke Government's recklessness, deception and negligence. I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places. More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places

Speaker: Mr CARLTON
Title: ECONOMIC CRISIS
text: Last week and this week the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) came out of his Budget bunker to tell the Australian people that Australia was in a (In- state of economic crisis. He told us that we were to have a tough Budget, a fall in living standards, and a cut in real wages, and that there would have to be all-round sacrifices. The Prime Minister went on the 60 Minutes program on Sunday night and said 'The party is over-finito'. But whose party was it in the first place? Who started the binge in the first place? Who declared that it was a party in the first place? Who squandered Australia's resources over three years of a business upswing, and who then has the hide to come and tell the Australian people that the party he started in the first place is now over? The Prime Minister said that the present economic crisis was akin to a state of war in Australia. I ask the Prime Minister: 'Whose side are you on in this war?' Who started the assault on the Australian economy in 1974, when, as President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Prime Minister was responsible for the highest level of strikes in Australia's history, the greatest single wage increase in one year that we have ever seen-35 per cent in one year-which, at one stroke, destroyed hundreds of thousands of jobs in Australian industry, businesses, farms and individuals? The assault in this war on our economy was begun by the Prime Minister in 1974 and it has been continued by Hawke, Keating, Crean and their mates over the last few years. The case that my colleague the member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) and I will put here this afternoon in this chamber is that this economic crisis is tragically unnecessary. It is brought not by any external assault on the Australian economy, but by the recklessness followed by the deception and negligence of the HawkeKeating Administration.

Speaker: Mr CARLTON
Title: ECONOMIC CRISIS
text: Well, the Minister Assisting the Treasurer who, in the course of his duties, spends most of his time replying to letters complaining about the fringe benefits tax. Let me take the House back for a moment to 1983, because it was back in 1983 that the present phase of the assault on the economy began. It was in this very chamber in April 1983 that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) stood up and told the assembled group here and the nation on television that the Government's economic strategy had two principal elements. The first of these was to bring about a more rapid rate of recovery than would otherwise be possible by spending and borrowing at a much higher rate than any government in Australia's peacetime history. That was the first principal mistake. It was to drive the Australian economy at a higher rate than any of the economies in the developed world and to do it on borrowed money. That was mistake No.1. Mistake No. 2 was to link wages to inflation. This was an insane step when the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and all its member countries were advising against it and when the experience of developed economies over the previous decade had shown that linking wages to inflation was a disastrous policy. But the Treasurer adopted these two elements of policy as central to Labor's economic strategy. It was inevitable that if we were to do that-given the basic incapacity in many respects of Australian industry to adapt quickly-we would run into serious balance of payments problems, and indeed we did. These balance of payments problems started to become very clear last year and they were exacerbated by a deterioration in Australia's terms of trade. I mention this because the deterioration in terms of trade is being used as the Government's alibi for all its mistakes. But Australia has had deteriorations in the terms of about trade before. We have also had other external shocks. We have had massive rises in the price of oil on two occasions; we have had a terrible deterioration in the world economy on a number of occasions; and we have had very bad droughts on a number of occasions. But one way or another we have managed to cope with those external pressures and disasters and get the economy back on the track. This time the Government is trying to use the deterioration in the terms of trade as an excuse for the fundamental mistakes it made in economic strategy in 1983. It was inevitable, regardless of what happened to the terms of trade, that if one did what the Treasurer did, one would run into massive balance of payments problems. Indeed, we did. When did the deterioration become evident? Certainly it was evident to the Treasurer-at least on the terms of trade side-in the last Budget. I quote from Budget Paper No. 1 page 73, of last August: A marked deterioration in the terms of trade is expected, reflecting primarily the relative weakness of world prices for our commodity-based products. Mr Braithwaite-How long ago was that?

Speaker: Mr CARLTON
Title: ECONOMIC CRISIS
text: That was a year ago and that was the first clear sign given to us by the Treasurer himself that Australia should brace itself for terms of trade problems. Other things became clear shortly after that. In October of last year we had a record balance of payments deficit of $1.6 billion. That was a very serious set of figures. The rest of the world could see what was going on, the Opposition was drawing attention to what was going on and a few economic observers and commentators in Australia were prepared to rock the Keating band-wagon and point out what was going on. People in the foreign capitals knew what was going on even earlier in February 1985. They had marked the Australian dollar down by 25 per cent following the Prime Minister's MX missile fiasco. But it was the underlying economics of the situation which originally led to the fall in the dollar. It was triggered by a perception that the Prime Minister was not fully in control of his Government. By the end of 1985 everybody around the world knew the fundamentals of the Australian economy. They knew exactly what would happen to it as a result of the Hawke-Keating policies because in November they marked the dollar down again.
