Speaker: Mr CARLTON
Title: ECONOMIC CRISIS
text: We are referring then to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer and their combined disastrous economic policies. I was referring to the fact that in November last year, because nothing had been done about the terrible balance of payments figures in October and nothing had been done as a result of terrible inflation figures or about excessive wage settlements in October, the dollar was marked down again on foreign markets. Indeed, it was marked down at the very time the Treasurer was travelling to New York and London to try to talk it up. The dollar dropped when the Treasurer went to New York. It dropped again when he went to London. It dropped because the foreign markets knew-they knew last November-that the game was up. The Government panicked and pushed up interest rates to their highest level since the Great Depression. Every small businessman, every farmer and every home owner with a mortgage lives to rue the day last November when the Government had to resort to a high interests rates policy because of the crumbling of its fiscal and wages policies. That happened last November. So everybody externally knew about this, but apparently the Government did not. On 3 January the Opposition put out its four point plan to arrest this situation and to get the economy back on track. It is to the eternal discredit of this Government that it did not accept any of that advice in January. Let the Australian people know that had the Government accepted that advice in January we would not have the need for a tough Budget tonight. The Government did not accept our proposals, which provided for a cut in Government spending; abandonment of the wages and productivity case then before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission; removal of the antibusiness tax policies-the fringe benefits tax. the capital gains tax and all that other rubbish: and a relaxation of foreign investment controls. These proposals, which I remind honourable members were made in January of this year, were ridiculed by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister. The tragedy of this situation is that many more people will be out of jobs, will lose their farms and businesses and will suffer supreme hardship because of the failure of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer to heed our advice in January. I merely quote something the Treasurer said in response to what we were saying as late as March. He said: This reveals something about the rhetoric of the Opposition about there being some sort of economic crisis, which are the words used in the matter of public importance coming up for discussion today.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: ECONOMIC CRISIS
text: When did he say that?

Speaker: Mr CARLTON
Title: ECONOMIC CRISIS
text: That was on 20 March 1986. He went on: It is some crisis when we have a 7.7 per cent nonfarm growth! The so-called words of crisis and pessimism coming from the Opposition on the economic outcomes are, of course, absolutely hollow. That is what the Treasurer said on 20 March. ije has said a number of other things. This was the deceptive phase as far as the Australian public was concerned-the attitude of 'let us lead them up the garden path'. In February the Prime Minister said: As far as the Government is concerned, we assert that the economic fundamentals of policy making in this country are right and will continue to deliver to this country the economic and the employment growth which has put the performance of this country so far ahead of anywhere in the rest of the world. That is what was said by the Prime Minister, Bob Hawke AC, MP, as recorded in Hansard of 13 February 1986.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: ECONOMIC CRISIS
text: Was that this year?

Speaker: Mr CARLTON
Title: ECONOMIC CRISIS
text: That was this year. On 20 March the Treasurer said in this House: The fact is that the Government's policy settings this year have been totally correct. Now we come to the really scandalous part of this, because on 9 May-only a few months ago-the Treasurer went to the Economic Planning Advisory Council, the main advisory body, and said: Overall, 1986 is emerging as a year of slower, but still satisfactory growth, a year in which we will see consolidation of the very strong gains of the past three years and-wait for itin which the economy can deal with the imbalance on our external account. That was on 9 May. Five days later, one day after disastrous balance of payments figures were released, we had gone from that supreme position to a banana republic. On 14May the Treasurer said that we were going down the shute. Obviously, if any more evidence were needed that this was a planned campaign of deception of the Australian community, it has to be provided by the juxtaposition of those two statements because one of them has to be an untruth. One of them has to be totally deceptive. I ask honourable members: Which of those statements is totally deceptive? Then there was the period of negligence. Did the Government do anything about the situation even in May? No, it did not. The Prime Minister decided to make a public address to the nation on television. So he did and he called for sacrifice. About a week later his mates in the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia responded to this call for national effort and sacrifice by closing the docks for a week. That is what happened. Then, still ignoring the requirement for a mini-Budget, still ignoring the request to cut back on wages, members of the Australian Labor Party went down to their national conference in Hobart and conducted a sham battle against the Left. But the enemy was on their side because while they were in Hobart talking about economic responsibility, Mr Sword, Mr Crean's successor as head of the Federated Storeman and Packers Union, was bringing Melbourne and Sydney to a halt by cutting off their petrol supplies just to demonstrate that union's economic responsibility. The tragedy of this economic crisis which is what it is; there is no about it-is that it need never have happened. The warnings were there. The warnings were in the Government's own publications if people had looked deeply enough into them. The warnings were there for foreign observers and were provided by the Opposition. But time and again the Government would not respond and, as a result, it stands condemned and will be responsible for the hardships that it will inflict on Australian people for the rest of this year and beyond.

Speaker: Mr HURFORD
Title: ECONOMIC CRISIS
text: Adelaide-Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer) (3.32)-Two months recess certainly has not done anything for the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton). That was a very pathetic effort. No wonder the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) is being pressed out of this place in order that Professor John Huson can come in and take over as shadow Treasurer. We have certainly just heard 15 minutes of a very pathetic effort which would make that at least something worthwhile for this Parliament. Nobody could do a worse job. One of the many contrasts between the Hawke Labor Government and the coalition Opposition relates to credibility. Credibility is a very important word in politics-a very important concept. This matter of public importance before the House today should be examined with that word 'credibility' in mind. We need just to look at the words in the matter of public importance. Let us just drag some of them out-emotional words such as 'recklessness', 'deception' and 'negligence'. They show a very small mind and certainly show the hypocrisy of the Opposition when it talks in those sorts of terms. It is not something that is worthy of this Parliament. If we want to have a look at irresponsibility let us look at those words such as 'recklessness', 'deception' and 'negligence' and let us just consider for a moment what their real meaning is. Let us just consider those words in terms of the Opposition's behaviour at Question Time today. Opposition members were so reckless, at a time when we have had two months recess from this place, that they brought into this Parliament not the grave concerns that there are at this time of economic difficulties for this country-they did not bring in such major concerns basically at Question Time-but matters relating to Mr Jusdoubt tice Lionel Murphy and his position. They brought in matters such as the discredited National Times article on the Treasurer (Mr Keating). They are the sorts of things that they have raised. If they want recklessness that certainly gives us an idea of what recklessness is. Mr Hand-Gutter politics.

Speaker: Mr HURFORD
Title: ECONOMIC CRISIS
text: As the honourable member the for Melbourne has just said, they are pursuing gutter politics and that is what we ought to be nailing on them. In talking about recklessness I note more significantly the example of the recklessness of the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and the $9.6 billion blowout in the last Budget that he sought to bring to this country. That is what recklessness means. Let us look at the word 'deception'. What about the Opposition being in favour of tax cuts on the one hand but being unable or unwilling to identify any major cuts in expenditure on the other hand? I just need to point out to the House that the Leader of the Opposition's promise to abolish the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax, the tax on lump sum superannuation payouts and the assets test would add an annual cost to the Budget of no less than $940m. How does anybody who pretends to be credible, reconcile that tax cut-type rhetoric with the expenditure promises made by the same Leader of the Opposition and his shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar, from whom we have just heard, when they list their wanted expenditure cuts to the order of $1.5 billion? Since then the National Party of Australia has gone haywire and has promised a further $500m package of goodies for the rural sector. That gives us some idea of the lack of credibility of the people opposite. If the Leader of the Opposition sadly ever took over as leader of the Government of this country there are only two ways in which he could finance his tax cuts and expenditure promises. The first would be irresponsibly to increase the deficit, as he did as Federal Treasurer in 1982-83 when the Liberals were thrown out of office with an election eve deficit projection, as I mentioned earlier, of $9.6 billion. The second would be to hold a massive sale of public sector assets such as Telecom Australia and the Commonwealth Bank in the same way as the Leader of the Opposition in my home State of South Australia wanted to do during his unsuccessful 1985 State election campaign and, indeed, as the Thatcher Government is doing in the United Kingdom. If we want credibility let us hear from the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar, in this House as to exactly what the Opposition would be doing in these circumstances. Instead we have these massive giveaways by way of promises relating to tax cuts on the one hand and promises of increased expenditure, such as the irresponsible $500m package of the National Party on the other hand. As I have said, all the Opposition has come up with is increases. So we can put in one phrase that it is reckless, deceptive and negligent. The Opposition's total and blatant hypocrisy in bringing this matter of public importance forward is evident, therefore, from the words of the matter itself. In contrast, let me say, in as measured a way as I possibly can, that the Government has a balanced and coherent strategy. This strategy will work and we have no intention of altering it. Of course, the strategy will be explained in further detail tonight when the Treasurer talks to the House and to the nation when giving his 1986-87 Budget Speech. Since this Government came to office we have made fundamental reforms aimed at restructuring the debilitated economy we inherited. Let me go through some of those reforms which will mean a far better structure for us to revive this country's economy in the near future. Deregulating the financial markets so that we have an efficient and innovative financial sector is just one of those reforms. We are ready now to respond to the needs of entrepreneurs in the business community generally. On the other hand, the coalition parties when in government could only aspire to deregulation but they never did things. Without floating the dollar we would never have had the depreciation that this country so desperately needs. This economy has needed it. For 20 years we have had an overvalued dollar and the result of an over-valued dollar was the decimation of our manufacturing industry. Now a whole range of previously uncompetitive industries is competitive again, particularly and most importantly our manufacturing industry. We brought down the most fundamental and far-reaching post-war tax reform despite the dishonest and self-interested bleatings of people in the Opposition. The rorts have been removed and still more will be removed. Personal marginal tax rates will be lowered and the company tax system reformed to remove the double taxation of dividends. The coalition always talked of tax reforms but it never did anything about them. Of course, the leader of the Opposition presided over the most scandalous explosion of tax avoidance and evasion that this country has ever experienced. He could not or would not do anything about it then, and now he has lost his chance forever, I am glad to be able to say for the sake of this country. I shall say something about wages policy. We have negotiated the accords marks I and II under which over 600,000 new jobs have been created, reducing the unemployment rate from over 10 per cent to just over 8 per cent and this occurred despite an increase in the participation rate to record levels, We have had three years of strong, positive and real growth in the economy, thanks to the accords mark I and II. Let us contrast that with the promised actions of the Opposition. It would have us having a market for wages. It would have us having a situation such as that which is being demonstrated by the plumbers and gas fitters right now with what they are seeking to impose on Australia-namely, a breakout from the accord. It would have us determining wages in the law of the jungle with the rich getting richer and the poor getting poorer. That is the sort of wages determination policy that it would have, and it would be in such strong contrast to the accord. I pay tribute to the trade union movement, which has been the other great party to the accord. It has meant that those in the work force have made their sacrifices in wage restraint for those outside the work force. Without that restraint and without the accord, we would not have had the great advance in creating over 600,000 new jobs. There is a sharp contrast between the coalition's policies and ours in relation to the manufacturing sector. We even had an interjection from the honourable member for Forde (Dr Watson) about our currency being undervalued now. I think that that was the effect of his intervention. He certainly suggested that he did not agree with me saying that our currency had been overvalued. I say to him that it is necessary to look only at the lack of competitiveness in our manufacturing industry to realise that that is not so. The need was there to do something about an overvalued dollar, and now that we have done so we shaH be in a position to re-industrialise this country. Under the Opposition's policies we had doubledigit unemployment, with hundreds of thousands of families thrown into poverty. Under those policies we had double-digit inflation as well, and we had a blow-out in the deficit. I have mentioned the deficit of $9.6 billion that we inherited. We had industrial disputes three times higher than they are now. Company profits were destroyed and there was accordingly a lack of investment. We had a 17 per cent wages blowout. Let me contrast that with the fine record of achievement during the three years of the Hawke Labor Government, I am proud to be able to remind the House of the results of our economic management. Real gross domestic product had declined by nearly one per cent in 1982-83, the last year of the previous Government. Over the past three years it has averaged an annual growth rate of 4.7 per cent. I have mentioned employment increasing and unemployment falling. Australia has one of the best records in this and in industrial disputation statistics of any other country in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. Generally, living standards have increased. I repeat that the Government has a fine record. I remind the House once again of what has happened in this latest crisis which we are addressing, and that is the decline in the terms of trade. Last year alone the figures fell by 14 per cent, to a post-depression low. The honour be speaking after me, will give some examples of what this has meant in the decline in the prices that we are getting for many of our products that we export. For instance, between 198182 and 1985-86, average coal export prices fell from $US54.85 a tonne to $US39.41 a tonne, a fall of 28 per cent. The most recent price is about $US38.72 a tonne. I could go on. The honourable member for Barton may find time to talk about wheat, wool, iron ore, alumina, beef and other items. He may have time to give examples of how things are affecting us over which we have no control. The price of our exports has driven Australia to the difficulties which we are now facing and which the Government is addressing, and we shall hear more about the Government's policies this evening. The Leader of the Opposition is on record as saying: 'The times will suit me'. He is gleeful at the troubles that Australia is suffering. I tell him that the times will not suit him. He wiJI have to put his policies on record in detail very soon. In fact, he will have to do so on Thursday night. The people will not put up with more vacillating on his part and mere rhetoric. The people will want details. I draw attention to a leading article in the Sydney Morning Herald of only a couple of days ago. It is headed 'The Budget and Mr Howard'. The editorial asks how tough he is. It states: When Mr Keating unveils his . . . Budget, and the disadvantaged interest groups are squealing, Mr Howard must remind voters that his Budget would have been even tougher. He will have to get that on record. I opened my remarks today by talking about credibility, and there is not much credibility on the benches opposite. There is even less credibility now, and that will remain the position unless the Leader of the Opposition, in replying on Thursday night, gives details of what his so-called Budget would be.

Speaker: Mr COBB
Title: ECONOMIC CRISIS
text: The people of Australia who have listened to the psuedo Treasurer, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford), could be forgiven if they thought that the economy was in great shape, bearing in mind the diatribe that they would have heard. Everyone in Australia knows that the country is on its knees. The economy is in a mess and yet the Minister handed out to us the sort of stuff that we have just heard. In the short three years that the Government has been in office it already stands condemned on just about every issue that it has touched. For example, in ministeries as diverse as those dealing with foreign policy and Aboriginal affairs we have had the ridiculous MX missile decision and the absurd land rights decision. On social security, we have had the unjust asset-test pension decision. I could continue. In no area, however, has negligence been more prevalent than in that of economic policy. In the eyes of the Australian people the 'world's greatest Treasurer' is now fighting to save his medal from rusting away. The chicken Hawke is seeing all his chickens come home to roost. The economic plug has been pulled and we have now moved into a downward vortex. We are running twentythird out of twenty-four OECD countries in several of the major economic indicators. Let us go through some of those. Inflation in this country is running between 8 per cent and 9 per cent. At the same time, the inflation rate of our trading partners is running between 0 per cent and 2 per cent. I am thinking of countries such as West Germany, the United States of America and Japan. We are falling behind. We have virtually the highest interest rates in the world and the highest real interest rates in this country since the Great Depression. The Government has been trumpeting about the growth rate. It is slowing down, and that is because it was built on high spending and borrowed money. I could give any family of this nation $100,000 and it could live well while it was spending that sum. However, the day comes when money has to be paid back, and that is what is happening now. The Government has trumpeted also about job creation; it has bragged about it. It is now turning round and we are moving into a period of spiralling unemployment, which will continue right through this year and next year. The Government's job creation has been based on borrowed money, the bulk of which has been spent in non-productive areas, such as jobs in the Public Service and in other shonky job creation schemes. In the Community Employment Program area alone, $1,1 OOm has been spent. There have been things like Priority One. The deficit is just about the most devastating economic indicator of all. Let us look at the overseas debt. When this crew took over the overseas debt was running, in round figures, at about $25 billion gross. That was high enough, but what is it today? It has gone over $80 billion. It took 83 years since Federation to get to $25 billion. In three years it has more than trebled to over $80 billion, and next year it will go over $100 billion. In comparing this Government with the Whitlam Government, which everyone condemns, I think we should look at certain factors. The Whitlam Government was condemned, but at least it was open about the things it did. I think this Government is more devious and more cunning and it is getting away with things far worse. Let us look at how our dollar is going. It has dropped to around US60c, or 50c on the trade weighted index basket, and the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the world's greatest Treasurer, is using interest rates to prop it up. At the end of last year he went through the exercise of shoving interest rates up from about 14 per cent to 21 per cent, which nearly crippled every small business and farmer in this country, the wealth producers of this country. He finally saw the error of that method and he laid off that for a while. But what happened two or three weeks ago when the dollar started to plummet again? He rang up the Reserve Bank again and in a period of one week alone interest rates went up 3.4 per cent. He is back to his old tricks. All this will mean is that all available money will go into servicing interest rates and there will be none left over to spend elsewhere in the community. Let us look at the tax indicator. This Government has gone tax mad. In the last 12 months alone we have had tax after tax after tax introduced. The superannuation lump sum tax has been brought in. There has been an attempt to bring in a compulsory 3 per cent superannuation tax. The negative gearing measures have almost destroyed the rental industry. We have had the entertainment tax and the assets test tax on pensioners. Mr Nehl-Disgraceful.

Speaker: Mr COBB
Title: ECONOMIC CRISIS
text: It is disgraceful. We have had the introduction of the capital gains tax and now we have the fringe benefits tax. This Government seems to have a motto: If it moves, tax it; if it does not move, apply a death duty to it. Let us look at the fringe benefits tax. What does the Premier of Western Australia, Mr Burke, say about the fringe benefits tax? He is against it. What does Mr Bannon of South Australia say about the fringe benefits tax? He thinks it is ridiculous. What does Mr Cain of Victoria say about the fringe benefits tax? He thinks it is iniquitous. What does Mr Unsworth of New South Wales say about the tax? He thinks it is an administrative nightmare. What does Mr Warburton of Queensland think about the tax? He also thinks it is ridiculous. The fringe benefits tax, the latest in a long list of taxes, will only create three Ps in this country: Poverty, paper and public servants. The most stupid example surfaced just recently. Last night after midnight, at a quarter past twelve a doctor was called out to an urgent caesarian. But before he started his car to drive away he had to make eight entries in his log book. - MJ: Chynoweth-What a load of rubbish.

Speaker: Mr COBB
Title: ECONOMIC CRISIS
text: It is not rubbish; it is the truth. A person· from a bllsiness in Dubbo came into my office the other day. His business has already make 16,000 entries in its log books in the first month alone. People In my electorate are saying: 'To hell with the log books'. They are putting them in the glove box and saying that at the end of the three month period they will fabricate the entries and fill in their log books. As every Labor Premier in Australia has said, it is an administrative nightmare; it is absolute nonsense. The Government has completely lost its grip on reality. It has no concept of how to apply these taxes. It is killing people's initiative to work. It is abolishing the incentive of the people in this country to invest. It is rewarding failure and idleness. If one looks around the Government benchesthere are not many Government members here today; only about thtee-one sees that they are awash with trendies and academics, most of whom have never done a day's work in the real world in their live-. If one has a look at the record of the man running the show, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), one sees that he has only come through the trade union movement and that when he led that all he did was introduce violence and aggression into it. He introduced disruption - nd vandalism to the country and I doubt that th- country will ever get rid of it.

The Liberal primary vote was down and if there was not a whole host of Independents stooging the public and doing their best to run a cover for the political party of those opposite, that sort of swing would not have occurred. What we are concerned with here today are the long term problems of the national economy which require long term solutions based on honesty, courage and the integrity of the interests of this nation, rather than the deceit, cynicism and failure to admit the mistakes of the past that characterises those opposite who have led this country into this predicament across 30 of the last 36 years. Today we have seen their perverted, distorted view of history and the way in which the nation's economy has panned out. Every national commentator who is respectable in the remotest sense agrees that this is a long term problem that requires long term solutions. The reality for those opposite, which they do not like to hear, is that for the vast majority of that time over which these problems have accrued they have been the people in government. To put a finer point on it, for five of the last seven years of conservative rule their present leader was the Treasurer of this nation, the man who had the opportunity to fix these long term problems but did not, and in fact went on to exacerbate them. It is those opposite and their political forefathers who created the economic and industrial structure of this economy that has left us as a nation vulnerable to the collapse in the price of our exports. Now, as usual, the Australian Labor Party-and we have been in office for a relatively short period-has to clean up the mess of those opposite. What are they doing in the meantime? They are busy playing politics, coming up with cliches, diversions from the national interest and destructive criticism. But worse still, as we have seen here today, they are proving to be most treacherous in their rhetoric. They are saying that this country cannot do it. They are saying that this country does not have the innate strength to come out of this predicament and to regain its place in the world. Those opposite take pride in belittling this country. They talk Australia down and, like that lightheaded Lightfoot from Western Australia, they are economic saboteurs of the first order. They seek to blame sections of the Australian population-the wage and salary earners-despite all the facts and all the statistics to the contrary. They seek to paint everybody who has ever had a social security benefit in his life as some sort of bludger and others as second-rate. Only they and their narrow-based constituency are reserved for anything but the worse. The truth of it is that history haunts the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and his ramshackle team. I refer to Black Jack MCEwen and his political marriage over 20 years ago of the rural big farm interests and the big city manufacturers-what Paul Kelly in a recent article in the Australian called 'The incredible alliance'. The article contains some interesting quotes from what was written by Paul Kelly, one of Australia's most eminent journalists and, apart from myself, in all humility, one of the best at the Australian newspaper. He said: The MCEwen legacy has hounded the Whitlam, Fraser and Hawke governments. He went on to say that Black Jack MCEwen, the Opposition's political forefather, was the godfather of the banana republic. That, my friends opposite, is the sad truth. This country is in this predicament because of the policies of Opposition parties in the past; and, despite the 30 of the last 36 years, the Hawke Labor Government will bring this country out of those problems to a new era of prosperity. Let us have a look at the present Leader of the Opposition and what he has done. During his tenure as Treasurer, he actively brought about a worsening of this problem. In pursuit of the Fraser resources boom-a boom that never happened-the false pretensions created an even further over-valued exchange rate. Exporters and existing import-competing industries suffered intolerably and closed down by the dozen. This action exacerbated inflation. It caused a diversion of financial and entrepreneurial resources away from manufacturing in a process that was compounded by a warped tax system. The proof of this, if those opposite really want to measure their existing Leader, is in a very interesting quote from the November 1981 Stan Kelly memorial lecture by none other than John Stone, one of the Opposition's activists on the campaign trail. This quote, my friends, shows the deliberate approach by the honourable member for Bennelong to lead this nation, when he was Treasurer, further into international debt. This is what the servant of the former Treasurer, the current Leader of the Opposition, had to say: It is only the external option-that is, increasing the current account deficit on the balance of payments-which increases the totality of resources available to the community and thereby gives an immediate increase in growth potential. That is what was said by John Stone in November 1981. It is on record that there was a deliberate policy by the Howard-Fraser Government to plunge this country further into international debt. It is on the public record. It was a deliberate policy, and it was one that served only to exacerbate the damage caused by their political forefathers in their early years. Yet despite that, they come in here this afternoon with this matter of public importance to blame this Government and to try to make political capital. Let me say this here and now: It is not our credibility but the Opposition's credibility that is on the line. The Australian public will remember the current Leader of the Opposition as the Treasurer of those dark years and they will know-if they do not know now, we shall make sure that they do by the next election-what the alternative really means. In the few remaining minutes that I have, let me dispel a couple of myths. I have some interesting figures. In 1980-81, Australia's current account deficit leapt from 1.7 per cent to 4.1 per cent of gross domestic product. In 1981-82, it leapt further to 6 per cent of GDP, which illustrates how suddenly and dramatically the current Leader of the Opposition, when he was Treasurer, put this country on the road to international indebtedness. The interesting point is that this Government has actually lowered the current account deficit as a proportion of gross domestic product compared with what it was when the honourable member for Bennelong was Treasurer-that is, in terms of gross domestic product, this Government has started to turn back the rot that the honourable member for Bennelong put into place. Another cliche put around the community by those opposite is that this foreign debt is somehow government-induced debt. This is not so. Of the $75 billion, only $15 billion is directly related to the Government; $60 billion of the foreign debt 'comes from the private sector. The other interesting point is this simple fact: If the prices of our commodities had not fallen in the manner in which they have-that is, if the terms of trade had not collapsed as they have-this country would be $6.5 billion better off and not only would there be no balance of payments crisis, as those opposite like to call it, but also there would not be a problem at all. The fact of the matter is that the world has cut our income by 3 per cent. This Government will not shirk from the hard task of bringing this country back to where it should be. But let us have no more of the hypocrisy from those opposite who for 30 of the past 36 years have run the country into the ground.

Title: TARIFF PROPOSALS
text: Lalor-Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce) (4.07)-I move: Customs Tariff Proposals Nos. 7 to 13 (1986) and Excise Tariff Proposals Nos. 5 to 8 (1986). The terms of the printed proposals are now being circulated to honourable members. The tariff proposals I have just tabled relate to proposed alterations to the Excise Tariff Act 1921 and the Customs Tariff Act 1982. The Proposals formally place before Parliament, as required by law, tariff alterations made by notices published in the Gazette during the recent recess. Excise Tariff Proposals Nos. 5,6 and 7 (1986), operative on and from 14 June, 26 July and 16 August respectively, provide for altered rates of excise duty on certain refined petroleum products resulting from the government's decisions on the pricing of indigenous crude oil and related issues. Customs Tariff Proposals Nos. 7, II and 13 (1986), operative on and from 14 June, 18 July and 16 August 1986 respectively, provide for corresponding alterations of rates of Customs duty. While rates of diesel fuel rebate alter in conjunction with these duty changes, the rebate rate for eligible primary production has been maintained as a 100 per cent rebate of the duty. The rebate rate changes for eligible mining operations also effectively mean no increase in duty payable. Excise Tariff Proposals No. 8 (1986), operative on and from 1 August 1986, reduce the top marginal rate of excise on old oil produced offshore from 87 per cent to 80 per cent. This concession, announced by the Government on 28 July 1986, will remain in force for the remainder of 1986-87. However, should the Bass Strait import parity price recover to $20 per barrel before the end of the financial year this arrangement will be reviewed. Customs Tariff Proposals No.8 (1986), operative on and from 15 April 1986, implement changes to remove the 2 per cent revenue duty on certain agricultural chemicals falling within item 38.11 in Schedule 3 to the Customs Tariff Act 1982. This action has been taken to implement part of the Government's economic and rural policy statement announced by my colleague the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) and permits the duty-free entry of these chemicals. Customs Tariff Proposals Nos. 9 and 12 (1986) provide for the duty-free entry of certain goods of New Zealand origin. Custom Tariff Proposals No. 9 (1986), operative on and from 1 May 1986, remove the 5 per cent duty previously applicable on certain powered lawnmowers. This action follows a further review under the intermediate goods provisions of the Australia New Zealand closer economic relations trade agreement. Customs Tariff Proposals No. 12 (1986) remove the 4 per cent duty which had applied to certain furniture and parts of New Zealand origin. As a result of representations by the Australian and New Zealand furniture industries to their respective governments, agreement has been reached to bring forward by 12 months the removal of trade restrictions on these goods. The relevant changes are therefore operative on and from I July 1986. The two changes contained in Customs Tariff Proposals No. 10 (1986) are operative on and from I July 1986. The first change removes the 2 per cent revenue duty on sulphur falling within item 25.03 in Schedule 3 to the Customs Tariff Act 1982. This change forms part of the Government's decision on the report of the Government study group on fertiliser production and consumption in Australia and the Industries Assistance Commission's Report on Fertilisers. The other amendment provides for the continuity of the Government's decision on the Industries Assistance Commission's report on electric motors and generating sets. This decision was originally implemented by Customs Tariff Proposals No.5 (1986), operative on and from 18 April 1986, but some restructuring of the Customs Tariff Act was required on I July IP86 because of the introduction of the revised system of tariff preferences for developing countries on that date. The rates originally implemented by Customs Tariff Proposals No.5 (1986) are not altered in any way by the current proposals. Summaries of alterations contained in these proposals have been prepared and are being circulated for the information of honourable members. I commend the proposals to the House. Speaker: Mr YOUNG
Title: REMUNERATION AND ALLOWANCES
text: I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. This Bill gives effect to several Government decisions relating to the remuneration of parliamentarians, judges and certain other public office holders. The prime purpose is to put into effect the Government's decision not to accept the Remuneration Tribunal's recommendation of an 11.7 per cent increase in parliamentary salaries. In presenting its 1986 review, the Tribunal stated that since I July 1984 the salary level of senators and members has been some 11.7 per cent less than ordinarily it should have been. The anomaly arose in the context of the 1984 review when the Tribunal established an equitable base for other groups in its jurisdiction by granting an II. 7 per cent increase, but this increase was not given to members by the Tribunal because of submissions by the Government and other parties. The same situation occurred in 1985 when the Tribunal drew attention to the anomaly but did not act in view of submissions by the Government and the Opposition parties. In 1986 the Tribunal noted similar submissions from the Government and the parties, but determined an II. 7 per cent increase on the basis of what the Tribunal saw as compliance with its statutory obligation and fairness and equity. The Government announced, on 1 July, its intention not to accept the increase. While we recognise that parliamentary salaries are subject to a considerable anomaly and that in some cases this may be placing some strain on the resources of individual members, we have agreed that parliamentarians must, in the current economic climate, forgo any recommended increase in salary above national wage case increases. This Act therefore amends Tribunal determinations 7 and 8, relating to additional salary for parliamentary office holders and basic salary of senators and members, so that existing salaries are increased only by the outcome of the recent national wage case. The basic salary of a member will then be $45,543; had the Tribunal's determination remained in force it would have been $50,871. As Remuneration Tribunal determinations come into effect on the date specified by the Tribunal, which in this case was I July 1986, the Act also allows for the alteration to the determinations to be effected retrospectively. The increased salary which has been paid to members since I July will therefore be required to be repaid and appropriate arrangements will be put in place. Because ministerial salaries are fixed by Government decision, Ministers have not received any payment by way of the anomaly element. The Bill also withdraws any entitlement to an 11.7 per cent increase in parliamentary superannuation benefits. Part III of the Bill amends the Judicial and Statutory Officers (Remuneration and Allowances) Act to give effect to Tribunal recommendations regarding the salary and allowances of judges and members of the Interstate Commission. It provides for salaries to be increased by national wage case decisions only; allowances are to be adjusted in line with cost of living increases. The opportunity has been taken in Part IV of the Bill to alter the mechanism for increasing the annual appropriation for ministerial salaries under the Ministers of State Act so as to avoid continual alterations to the Act. To remove the need for recurrent legislative amendment, it is proposed to amend the Ministers of State Act to provide that in future the limit should be fixed by regulation under the Act. The limit will continue to be set on the basis of the actual salaries payable to Ministers as decided by the Government following recommendations of the Remuneration Tribunal. The regulations will of course be subject to the same parliamentary scrutiny and the same disallowance provisions as other regulations. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill. Leave granted for second reading debate to proceed forthwith.

Speaker: Mr SPENDER
Title: REMUNERATION AND ALLOWANCES
text: The reasons for the Remuneration and Allowances Alteration Bill 1986 have been outlined by the Special Minister of State (Mr Young), save for one which is the most important of the reasons. It is because of the parlous economic circumstances in which this country finds itself that Bill is being put up by this Government. Those economic circumstances are directly due to a matchless combination of arrogance, incompetence and recklessness that this Government has exhibited in its economic policy planning, if one could call what this Government has done for some time policy planning. The Special Minister of State has pointed out that there are anomalies. I agree that there are anomalies. Outside this House he has pointed to the need to pay parliamentarians a proper salary. I agree with those views but I also agree with the views that he has expressed on behalf of the Government to the effect that now is not the time for any anomalies to be dealt with. It is for members of parliament to present an example to people when it comes to restraint in these harsh economic times. As the honourable member for Denison says, it never is a time to catch up. He is in fact right. It is worthwhile recalling that in 1975 a Level 2 public servant was paid, I think, $20,000 and a member of parliament was also paid $20,000. In 1986 a Level 2 public servant is paid, I believe, $53,632 and a member of parliament is paid $45,543. The salary of a public servant has gone up by 168 per cent and the salary of a member of parliament has gone up by 127 per cent, which says something as to who runs things in this country. It is necessary to exercise restraint and, save for one qualification, we have no opposition to the Bill. The qualification relates to the provision in the Bill that provides that ministerial salaries be increased by regulation and not by amendment as required under the Members of State Act 1952. We oppose that provision and ordinarily we would have voted against it but in the circumstances, Budget day, we do not propose to call a division on it. We do not think it is appropriate that that kind of a matter be dealt with by regulation and we think it is better that the old procedure, even if it is somewhat cumbersome, be pursued so that a closer public scrutiny can be given to increases in ministerial salaries.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: ACCOUNTS
text: On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 248th report of the Committee relating to the Report of the Auditor-General-April 1985, and- I seek leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report. Leave granted,

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: ACCOUNTS
text: I thank the House for its courtesy. Following the tabling of the report of the Auditor General in April 1985-honourable members will be aware that each year the Committee examines recently published reports of the Auditor-General-the Committee sought written submissions from 10 departments and five statutory authorities in respect of 22 items. Further information and clarification by way of supplementary submissions were sought from six departments and one statutory authority. Report 248 is a departure from the usual practice of the Committee. Due to an increasing work load the Committee decided that the Parliament's attention should be drawn to the salient features of the Auditor-General's report in future. Consequently the principal matters on which the Committee sought comment from departments and authorities were addressed but public hearings were not held on any of the matters raised on this occasion. This report comments on the responses of the departments and authorities to criticisms raised by the Auditor-General. Conclusions drawn by the Committee reflect remedial action taken or proposed to be taken in addressing those items. In particular there were three matters that the Committee wished to bring to the attention of members of Parliament. The first was the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations wage pause program; the second, the Department of Territories administration of the Commissioner for Housing loans scheme and, third, the financial statements of the Australian National University. The Special Employmentrelated Programs Act 1982 provided for the expenditure of up to $200m through a wage pause program of public sector job creation. The money partly represented expected savings from the 12 months suspension of salary increases for Commonwealth employees under the salaries and wages pause legislation. Under the established guidelines the States were required to submit employment projects to the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations and if considered suitable details were forwarded to the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) for approval. Projects which were to receive consideration for approval were required to be labour intensive and to promote greater equality of opportunity particularly for the long term unemployed. The audit review of the scheme sought to establish whether the procedures introduced to administer the program within the area of Commonwealth responsibilities were consistent with the aims and objectives. The Committee was disturbed by the administrative difficulties developed following hasty implementation of the wage pause program, and in particular from the inadequacy of interdepartmental co-ordination. In view of this concern and the fact that this program ceased in mid-1984, the Committee sought supplementary submissions from both the Employment and Industrial Relations Department and the Finance Department with respect to another similar employment program. The House will be familiar with that program, the community employment program. While this program is not subject to audit, the Committee considered it important to assess the administrative arrangement governing it. From the respective departmental submissions, it is clear that the administrative and financial arrangements for the community employment program differ quite markedly from those which applied to the wage pause program. The Minister for Finance has limited executive responsibilities and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations clearly has carriage of the legislation and program administration. Clearer working guidelines and funding through annual appropriations have, to a large degree, clarified the obligations and responsibilities of the agencies concerned. The second matter was the housing loans scheme operational in the Australian Capital Territory. Under the Housing Ordinance 1982 the Commissioner for Housing in May, subject to the control of the Minister for Territories, administers schemes for providing or assisting in providing dwellings in the Australian Capital Territory. On 10 September 1984 the Minister for Finance, pursuant to concern expressed by Cabinet about the management of funds in the scheme, requested the Auditor-General to perform an audit of the recent operations of the scheme in the light of recent over-commitment of funds. Audit findings were that, first, the housing trust account was overexpended from 4 July 1984 to 18 July 1984 in breach of section 34 of the Audit Act, secondly, that there were deficiencies in the administration for controlling equipment; and, thirdly, that the estimated shortfall of $7.9m in funds was an unreliable estimate. The Committee was informed that the Department has now instituted amended procedures and practices in order to eliminate any future problems with over-commitment of funds. Further, the Department has implemented a range of measures to improve the financial and administrative procedures and staffing arrangements of the Housing Branch. These amended which procedures and arrangements implement many of the recommendations of a joint review of the scheme by the Public Service Board and the Department of Territories, conducted during September 1984, and of the Fisher Review conducted during the first half of 1985. The Steering Committee for Housing Loans is continuing to meet on a regular basis to implement the longer term recommendations of the joint review report and will continue to do so until all recommendations are satisfactorily implemented. The Committee notes that Audits comments on these amended schemes and procedures should eliminate future problems. However, I want to emphasise, as I particularly have this view, that the Committee will continue to monitor the Department's operation of the scheme and may subject it to further review in the light of future comments and the Committee's own consideration of more detailed information to be made available to it by the Department. The Auditor-General also reported on an inspection of the accounts and records of financial transactions of the Australian National University for the year ended 31 December 1983. Among other things audit noted serious deficiencies existed in supporting documentation for the university's 1983 draft financial statements, both in their original form and in the revised draft submitted some months later. Audit was concerned that in some respects the university's accounting practices were at variance with those prescribed in the guidelines on the form and standard of financial statements of Commonwealth undertakings issued by the Minister for Finance in May 1983. The Committee notes that the University has significantly reformed its financial administration and that this reform process is continuing. The Committee anticipates continued improvement in the University's financial administration, particularly with reference to its financial statements. The Auditor General now reports twice each year on audits undertaken. In addition separate reports are made throughout the year on efficiency audits performed by the Auditor-General, and annual reports on the financial statements and his activities. During the currency of the examination of the Auditor-General's report of April 1985 the Auditor-General presented an annual report for 1984-85 on his operations. This was the first time the Auditor-General had reported in this manner. The report referred to, amongst other things, a number of issues concerning the role and proper function of the Auditor-General, particularly his relationship with the Executive.
