Speaker: Mr KEATING
Title: ACCOUNTS
text: I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. In doing so, I present the Budget for 1986-87. Over the past year the factors which determine Australia's national prosperity have changed dramatically. The strong economic growth and the huge employment growth of the last three years have now been slowed due to the sudden collapse of our export earnings. The prospects for our future growth, built on the expectation that we could readily sell our traditional products, have been substantially diminished. Many Australians have wondered why the economy was doing so well in 1985 and yet, apparently, doing so poorly in 1986. The answer lies in the dramatic collapse in world commodity prices since late last year. We have been placed in a position where we are failing to cover the cost of our imports to the tune of more than a billion dollars a monthand inevitably our growth had to slow. With the world having slashed our national income by over $6 billion we could not continue on as though nothing had happened. To try would see the world force destructive adjustment on Australia making it hostage to the international financial community. And that is not a position acceptable to this Government. We believe that Australia must maintain control over its own destiny and this can only be done by facing the problem squarely and making the remedial changes quickly and decisively. This the Government will do through this Budget and other policy changes. It is imperative that our domestic economy and our standard of living adjust to our changed trading circumstances so that we can make an early return to higher growth and stronger employment. What precisely are the adjustments required? As a nation, if we are to become more independent and self-sufficient, we need to invest more and consume less. In other words, we must save for the future rather than spend for the present. The Government can help this process directly by spending less and borrowing less, thereby improving the climate for lower interest rates and for private sector investment. The savings and tax decisions in this Budget are also designed to restrain the growth of private consumption. But the Budget alone cannot achieve all of the changes Australia requires. It is also essential that Australians exercise restraint over wages and prices. We simply cannot allow the inevitable inflationary effects of the dollar's fall to feed into our cost structure. Contrary to the beliefs of some, Australia is well equipped to make the adjustments to rectify its problems. We have made enormous progress in the past 3 years in modernising and freeing up the economy. We have a much lower wage cost structure, a vibrant financial sector, and vastly more competitive industries than a few years ago. While we have now encountered serious difficulties in our primary export markets, through our combined efforts and continued restraint we can tllrn those efforts towards new opportunities. For these reasons, the Budget incorporates a very large cut in spending and a very large cut in Government borrowing. In making these vital decisions we have sought to ensure that the burden of change is spread as fairly as possible across the community. Even in difficulty, however, we have maintained the Labor Party's traditional commitment to the most needy. But we have not shirked our responsibility to take hard decisions where these have been required. Reflecting this, the Government has been able to bring the deficit down from $5,726 million last year to $3,503 million this year. I repeat, this Budget cuts the deficit by $2,223 million to $3,503 million. It is also important to understand that while in total the Commonwealth has budgeted for a deficit of $3.5 billion, much of this deficit arises from spending abroad on defence equipment and other items. Allowing for these overseas transactions there will be an estimated domestic budget surplus of $805 million. Combined with reductions in State borrowings, the large cut in the Budget deficit will dramatically lower government demand for borrowed funds. In fact, total public sector borrowings will be cut by more than $2t billion in 1986-87. The Government's bond selling program has been cut from $5.7 billion last year to around $3 billion this year. As a result, the net bond selling task will be zero. I would point out that the large reduction in the deficit this year has been made notwithstanding economic developments tending to increase it. Wage restraint tends to lower taxes more than outlays in the short term. As I shall discuss later, the Budget figuring incorporates a 2 per cent discount to wages in the next National Wage Case. Without that assumption, the deficit would have been some $400 million less. The Government's resolve and achievement in this Budget is well reflected in the fact that if we had taken no action on outlays or receipts the deficit would have been $7.5 billion. We have brought it down by $4 billion, or more than half. NA Madam Speaker, the deficit reduction in this Budget has been accomplished by an examination of outlays of unprecedented rigour. If we had done no more than provide for ongoing programs, outlays would have increased by 2.7 per cent in real terms. We have cut this back to zero real growth. To achieve this result, nearly $3 billion has been cut from existing programs. Cutbacks have been made in most areas, with major reductions falling on social security, health, education, defence and overseas aid. In social security, the Government has decided on cutbacks of over $500 million. Included in those decisions, future six monthly indexation increases to beneficiaries will continue to be paid in full but will be deferred for six weeks. This means that the 4 per cent increase due in early November will now be paid in midDecember. In addition, the measures announced last year to relax income testing arrangements for pensions and benefits will be delayed 8 months until July 1987. These are the only changes to the general pension and benefits area. While seeking a contribution from this part of the Budget towards the resolution of our national problems, the Government has ensured that there will be no reductions in any existing pension or benefit payments. What is being required is a minimal sacrifice when compared with that being asked of wage and salary earners. There will be a crackdown on cheating and fraud in the social security system. We will not compromise our deep commitment to assist the genuinely needy. But abuse of the system will not be tolerated. Special reviews will be conducted by teams of officers to identify and disqualify those wrongfully receiving unemployment benefits. Additionally, reporting requirements for all unemployment beneficiaries will be tightened and it will be much harder for New Zealand citizens who are visiting Australia to qualify for unemployment and other benefits. There will also be reviews of sole parent beneficiaries to verify continuing eligibility. The Government is committed to implementing the Australia Card with a photograph, which will also assist in combatting social security fraud. Child maintenance arrangements are being reformed so that non-custodial parents will shoulder more financial responsibility for their children, rather than throwing the burden onto the taxpayer. In line with the Government's aim to target welfare assistance to the most needy, the family allowance for student children aged 16 and 17 will be income tested so that families with household income exceeding $39,000 will no longer receive it. In the same vein, the Government will in this Budget provide further assistance to the most needy, low income families with children and to the handicapped. These discretionary adjustments are detailed in the Budget Papers. The Government has taken a range of measures to help contain the growing cost of Australia's health system. Spending in this area will be cut by $300 million. First, strict measures have been adopted to reduce what were clearly excessive pathology charges by some medical practitioners. Second, the wage restraint asked of the workforce at large has been extended to medical practitioners by deferring increases in schedule fees until I November 1986. Third, the maximum patient contribution for medical services-I stress the maximum, not the typical-is to be raised from $10 to $20 from 1 November. Fourth, the bed day subsidy to private hospitals will cease from 1 October 1986, but some charitable hospitals will continue to receive assistance. But even with these savings, and particularly with the recent increases in salaries for nurses, the cost of the health system is continuing to rise. The Government therefore believes that the Medicare levy should be increased so that it makes a greater contribution to health costs and so that Medicare is self-financing. Accordingly, the Medicare levy will rise by a quarter of a per cent to 1.25 per cent from 1 December. Increasing the levy is a more equitable means of responding to unavoidable increases in health costs than the alternative of severely curtailing Medicare benefits. Pharmaceutical benefits have been another area of burgeoning costs in the health system. This has been a concern to both the Government and the very sick. New arrangements will reduce costs to the health system and provide relief to those most in need. From 1 November prescription drug users now paying a $5 contribution will pay up to a $10 maximum. New safety net arrangements mean individuals and families requiring more than 25 prescriptions a year will receive prescriptions beyond that number free of charge. Pensioners will continue to receive items on the Pharmaceutical Benefits list free of any charge. The Government believes it is only fair that participants in the higher education system share some part of its costs. Consequently a charge of $250 per year for all higher education students will be introduced in 1987 to offset administration costs. This charge represents only a small part of the cost of providing higher education, and will contribute towards an additional student intake of 3000 in 1987. Lower income families will be protected; holders of tertiary allowances and post-graduate awards and overseas students paying the overseas student charge will not be affected. Spending on defence is to be held at 1 per cent real growth, saving $190 million, and overseas aid will be cut by $140 million from its forward estimate. Expenditure on the new Parliament House is to be reduced by $30 million, sports facilities by $8 million and the Bicentennial Program by $25 million. The number of Commonwealth public servants will be reduced by 2000 over the year to June 1987. The Government has made numerous other expenditure cuts in reaching its $3 billion expenditure savings; details are set out in the Budget Papers. Madam Speaker, the overwhelming concern of the Government in bringing down this Budget has been to achieve an outcome appropriate for a nation with a trading problem of the magnitude now facing Australia. That is why spending has been held to zero real increase. That is why we have sought to produce the lowest practicable budget deficit. The Government has held outlays and the deficit well below the trilogy requirements. Outlays as a proportion of gross domestic product have been reduced to 29.4 per cent, compared with 30.1 per cent last year and 30.4 per cent the year before. The deficit has been reduced to only 1.4 per cent of gross domestic product, back to the average prevailing during the late 1950s and the 1960s. It is the fourth consecutive fall from the 5 per cent in prospect that we inherited from the Coalition Government in 1983. In pursuit of this objective and given the urgency of our predicament the Government has decided to lift the tax ratio about half a per cent above the 1984-85 level. This decision has been taken to achieve an even larger reduction in the deficit, and to do so in an equitable way. Our trilogy of fiscal commitments was directed at restraining the size of Government over the medium-term and we reaffirm that fundamental objective. The Government has been spectacularly successful in lowering expenditure growth and the deficit. Moreover, it is our objective to bring the tax ratio back to 25 per cent of gross domestic product next year. This year, however, the first stage of the very substantial cuts in personal income tax provided by the tax reform program will be delayed three months. These cuts-at the previously announced rates-will now apply from I December this year. The second and final stage-reducing the top marginal tax rates to 49 cents and 40 centswill apply from I July 1987 as scheduled. Legislation implementing both stages is being introduced tonight. These cuts-as well as improving incentivewill return to taxpayers about three times the revenue raised by the tax reform package. Madam Speaker, the Government has adopted a number of other revenue measures. In the main, the measures will restrain real household disposable incomes and consumption, consistent with the need for our living standards to be trimmed for a time. Wholesale sales tax will be increased on a range of consumer products including luxury motor vehicles, wine, certain non-alcoholic beverages and swimming pools. The sales tax law is also to be amended with effect from midnight tonight to curtail avoidance of taxes on computer software. The excise on petrol and diesel fuel will increase by 3 cents per litre from tonight. Because of the existing diesel rebate arrangements, this additional excise will not fall upon farmers and miners. The rates of the Bank Account Debits Tax will be increased by up to a half from 1 December 1986. The tax deferral advantages enjoyed by some companies with substituted accounting periods will be phased out over three years. NA Madam Speaker, the Budget. I have outlined tonight will greatly assist Australia to adapt to the new international trading circumstances we face. However, budget policy must be supported by continued price and wage moderation. The restructuring of Australian industry facilitated by the depreciation of the dollar will accelerate provided we stay competitive with the rest of the world. Staying competitive means having a greater ability to supply our own market with Australian-made goods and to win a larger share of world markets. Over the past 3 years Australia's working men and women have shown commendable income restraint. More than any other single factor, their cooperation and good sense has been responsible for the creation of 630,000 jobs since April 1983. Over this period real labour costs have fallen by more than 7 per cent. It is not the fault of wage and salary earners that export prices have fallen. Just as it is not their fault that the dollar has fallen, pushing up import prices. But we cannot afford to let wages grow automatically in line with this price surge. If adverse trading conditions and a depreciating Australian dollar are the cause of the Consumer Price Index rising, it follows that to allow those increases to flow through automatically into wages would compound our problems. We would be adjusting our wages upwards not to compensate for the problem but to build the problem in. This would only lead Australia into a price and wage spiral. I am certain that all Australians will understand and accept that we cannot have our national income slashed by over $6 billion and at the same time seek to fully maintain our wages in real terms. Accordingly, at the next National Wage Case when the combined 4.0 per cent movement in the March and June quarter Consumer Price Index will be considered, the Government will argue to the Arbitration Commission that the proposed increase in wages be cut by 2 per cent. This means that wages will rise by 2 per cent less than the increase which would fully compensate for inflation. There are good and clear reasons for this. Last year award wages grew by 4 1/2 per cent. With a 2 per cent discount, wages are expected to grow at about the same moderate rates as in 1985-86. This means that over the course of the next year Australian wage increases will be broadly comparable with our major trading partners. A 2 per cent discount would therefore maintain our competitiveness and preserve our ability to compete on favourable terms with the rest of the world. The Government will also seek a further adjustment of the wage increase in the case commencing around April next year if economic conditions applying at the time warrant it. In determining its attitude to that case, the Government's main focus will continue to be on Australia's ongoing competitive position and our terms of trade performance. With its past record of success, the Government reaffirms its confidence in the Prices and Incomes Accord. The Accord framework will continue to deliver more economically and industrially responsible outcomes than any other real world alternative. The challenges now presented by severely depressed commodity prices demand a continuation of this approach. NA Madam Speaker, it will take some time for the ground lost in our export markets to be recovered, and a stronger growth path to be resumed. As a result, we expect growth in the non-farm economy to be around 2 1/2 per cent in 198687 compared with 4 per cent last financial year. Most of that growth will stem from our improved international competitiveness; it will show up in the winning of new export markets and the replacement of imports with locally produced goods. However, the lower growth rate means that fewer jobs will be created over the next year than in the last twelve months. Employment growth is expected to slow to between 1 1/2 and 2 per cent, and as a consequence, unemployment could rise a little. Just as it will take some time for the benefits of the depreciation of the dollar to flow through the economy, it will also take some time before the adverse price effects of the depreciation are behind us. Consequently, reflecting the recent falls in the dollar, we expect the Consumer Price Index to increase by around 8 per cent on average in 1986-87. However, the trend in the latter part of the year and beyond will be downward. Madam Speaker, the Budget. I am presenting tonight responds decisively to the new international challenge facing Australia. It constitutes one of the basic and fundamental responses required to permanently improve Australia's trading performance. It makes the major shift down in Government spending and borrowing that will permit the new investment opportunities to be seized: - real spending growth has been cut to zero; - the deficit has been dramatically brought back to its late 1950s and 60s levels; and - Government calls on the nation's savings have been substantially alleviated. This Budget provides Australia with the opportunity to surmount its economic problems and maintain control over its economic destiny. It demonstrates the Government's absolute determination to do what has to be done to safeguard Australia's economic future. It demonstrates once again that, by resolute action and by some sacrifice all round, there is no problem that we cannot face and defeat together. Madam Speaker, I now provide more details of the expenditure cuts that have been made. Budget outlays in 1986-87 are estimated to total $74,764 million. As I stated earlier, this represents zero growth in real terms. In the previous thirty years lower real rates of growth have been achieved on only three occasions. This outcome reflects the determined approach which the Government has adopted to expenditure control. Details of individual decisions are contained in the Measures section of Statement No 3; additional information will be provided, as appropriate, by the relevant Ministers. The Prime Minister will also be making a detailed statement on Public Service staffing matters in the next few weeks. NA I have already outlined our major initiatives in this area. I stress once again: The Government has a commendable record of directing assistance to those in greatest need. Over the term of the Hawke Government there have been significant increases in the real value of pensions and benefits, and large gains in assistance provided for children in low income families. This Budget continues the Government's focus on improving benefits for those in need, on removing anomalies and attacking fraud. In addition to the measures I have already announced, action is to be taken to prevent some people qualifying for dual benefits. From 1 November 1986, where a newly eligible war or defence widow pensioner is also eligible for a social security pension, the maximum level of the social security pension will be frozen at $60.05 a week. I mentioned earlier that some benefits to the most needy in the community were to be increased. To assist pensioners and low income families with children, there will be a $1 a week increase in the additional pension and benefit per child and a $1 a week increase in the rate of the Family Income Supplement from November 1986. OUTLAYS In recognition of the difficulties and additional costs facing disabled people who undertake employment or vocational training, the mobility allowance will increase to $11 a week from November this year. The handicapped child's allowance will increase by $7 per month to $92 per month from November 1986. And also from November, the orphan's pension will increase by $4.30 to $60 per month. A clear need has been established for the Government to provide additional income support for 16 and 17 year olds who are the victims of abuse within their own families or cannot live at home. Consequently, a Young Homeless Allowance of $23.28 a week has been introduced to supplement the income these young people receive from education allowances or unemployment benefits. Expenditure in 1986-87 for that purpose is estimated to be about $9 million. NA When dealing earlier with the Government's major proposals in the health portfolio, I stressed that we were adamant that health funding must be kept within reasonable bounds. Consequently, in addition to those other measures, we will investigate the payment of medical benefits which are growing at above average rates and review mechanisms for further restraining growth in health costs. The Isolated Patient Travel and Accommodation Assistance Scheme will be transferred to the States. Extra funding of $11 million this year and $22 million in a full year will be provided to the States and Territories to enable them to provide more effective arrangements. Funding has been increased in a number of important areas in the health portfolio. These include health promotion, public health, hepatitis B vaccinations, medical research, family planning and assistance to diabetics. NA I have already mentioned the Government's intention to impose an administration charge on higher education students. In addition, the overseas student charge currently applicable to university and CAE students will be extended to secondary, TAFE and other previously exempt higher education students from overseas. Together with increases in existing charges, this extension will yield $7.3 million, offsetting the costs of providing education to overseas students in Australia. An anomaly exists in current arrangements whereby some social security beneficiaries can receive both student allowances and pensions or benefits. This is to be removed for new entrants from the 1987 academic year, saving $4 million. A special payment of $15 per week will instead be made to invalid and sole parent pensioners who are also students to encourage their education and later employment prospects. NA There has been a significant re-ordering of priorities within this function and, overall, cut in spending. Flowing from last year's decision to implement the Priority One program, expenditure on job training programs will increase by $67 million, including an increased allocation of $33 million for the Australian Traineeship System. This accords with the Government's intention that training and education opportunities available to our young people be significantly enhanced. Increased emphasis on training is to be complemented by reduced emphasis on Government job creation schemes. Consequently, outlays under the Community Employment Program will be reduced by $90 million to $200 million. The 2 per cent wage discount recently applied to wages is to be extended to former Commonwealth Government employees and Defence Force personnel receiving Government superannuation benefits. NA Assistance to Aboriginals will undergo a significant change in emphasis following the Government's endorsement of the general principles espoused in the Miller Report on Aboriginal Employment Training. The emphasis of existing programs will be changed from short-term job creation and welfare measures towards policies to establish long term employment opportunities. Commonwealth expenditure directed towards Aboriginals will total $570 million in 1986-87. NA Real growth in defence spending has been cut to 1 per cent in 1986-87, a significant reduction on the 3.75 per cent allowed for in the Five Year Defence Program. Nevertheless, average real growth in defence spending under this Government remains greater than that under our predecessors. Recently the Government has begun the most thorough and comprehensive review of this country's defence priorities since the Second World War. In light of the Dibb Report and prevailing economic circumstances, the Government will now prepare a White Paper on Defence which will set down the development of Australia's defence capabilities well into the future. This report will reflect the need to maintain a real planning at achievable financial outcomes. Such a disciplined approach will ensure that essential changes can take place in equipment and force structure. NA The Special Broadcasting Service and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation are to be amalgamated, and their combined funding reduced by $16 million from last year's allocation. The specialised charter of the SBS will be preserved under the amalgamation. Gross savings from shared facilities, accommodation, equipment and administration in the amalgamated organisations should be about $2 million in 1986-87 and much greater in future years. We are also reducing the cost of administrative assistance to the arts. As a first step, the Australia Council's istrative expenses for 1986-87 are to be reduced by $1 million to allow increased support for the arts. A wide-ranging review of the Commonwealth's funding of museums is to be undertaken. The construction of the National Museum of Australia in Canberra will not proceed on the timetable previously conceived; its future will be considered following this review. INDUSTR y ASSISTANCE All production bounties other than those applying to fertilisers and shipbuilding are to be reduced by 20 per cent from tonight, saving $43 million. There will be a phased reduction in the shipbuilding bounty rate from 25 per cent to 20 per cent. The consumption subsidy for fertilisers will no longer apply to imported products and the savings will be reallocated to increase subsidy rates on locally manufactured phosphatic fertilisers. NA It is the Government's intention to shift some of the present burden from monetary policy. NA Madam Speaker, in conclusion I wish to return to the main theme of tonight's Budget. I have made it clear that our prime concern was to set in place the pre-conditions for a turnaround in the current account deficit. Already there is clear evidence that the underlying forces are working as expected. Last financial year there was a 7.4 per cent increase in the volume of Australia's exports. Import volumes declined quite sharply-in the first half of 1986 they fell at an annual rate of more than 10 per cent. This is the beginning of the necessary structural adjustments which I have described-the switching to new products and activities. But this welcome improvement in export volumes and reduction in import volumes were over-shadowed by the big falls in world commodity prices. As quickly as we lifted export volumes, export prices feU. And in the shorter term, while we still maintain our heavy dependence on primary exports, our problem with commodity prices is not going to go away. Large falls in import volumes are in prospect this financial year, and further export growth is expected. But once again we must expect those positive outcomes to be masked by poor prices. As a result, on present indications, little change is expected in our current account deficit as a percentage of GDP for 1986-87 as a whole. For seasonal and other reasons, we expect a number of large monthly deficits over the remainder of this calendar year. Madam Speaker, when this Government was elected to office in March 1983 we inherited from our Coalition predecessors a massively debilitated economy. Over the past three and a half years, with absolute determination and the co-operation of the Australian people, we have overcome these legacies. With historic levels of economic and employment growth and our sweeping reforms to the financial and taxation systems, our record of achievement is an enviable one. Earlier 1 said that by resolute action and some sacrifice all round we can face and defeat any problem. This means staying competitive with the rest of the world and trading out of our difficulties. Second Reading BILL 1986 Mr LIONEL BOWEN (Kingsford-SmithAttorney-General) (9.08)-I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. The purpose of the Bill I am introducing tonight is to amend the Freedom of Information Act 1982 and the Freedom of Information (Charges) Regulations to reduce administrative costs and increase revenues. The main points are: introduction of application fees for requests for access to documents and for internal review of decisions; to increase the hourly charge for search and retrieval of documents; to introduce an hourly charge for decision making time; to exempt persons seeking personal income maintenance documents from all charges and fees; to maintain after 1 December 1986 the present 45-day time limit for processing requests; to strengthen provisions for refusal of requests on workload grounds; to reduce the grounds for remission of charges; to reduce the obligations on agencies to publish section 8 and section 9 statements and to report statistics; and miscellaneous amendments of a minor nature. As is clear from the introduction of this Bill tonight, the Government continues to be concerned by the costs of operation and administration of the Freedom of Information Act and by the very low contribution made by users towards meeting those costs. Honourable members will recollect that in June 1985 the Government issued new directions designed to maximise disclosure of information whilst reducing the costs of administering the Freedom of Information Act. Administrative aspects of those measures, particularly the clearance role of my Department, have been valuable in reducing the number of disputes about release of information. Furthermore, costs of processing requests have continued to decrease as agencies gain experience and improve procedures. However, the other major aspect of the Government's directions-changes to the Charges Regulations designed to simplify charging procedures and recoup a more significant contribution by users of the legislationwere frustrated by the Senate when the amendments were disallowed on 13 November 1985. In 1984-85 the operation and administration of the FOI Act cost the Commonwealth between $16m and $19m, depending on the precise allowance made for overheads, and the preliminary figures for 1985-86 indicate a cost between $14m and $16m. Although there is some indication that the total number of requests is levelling off-preliminary estimates for 1985-86 are 36,000 to 37,000 requests as against 33,000 in 198485-it is clear that administration of the Act will continue to involve very substantial Commonwealth expenditure. It is also clear that under the present charging structure only very small contributions will be received from users of the legislation-about $22,000 in 1984-85 and perhaps $60,000 in 1985-86-or rather less than half a per cent of the administration costs. Australia simply cannot afford such a situation. The problems identified by the Government in June 1985 remain. Ways must be found to reduce costs and encourage efficient use of the Act. Economic circumstances are such that the Government must take action now. In recent months an inter-departmental committee has been examining options for FOI costs savings. This Bill draws on the work of that Committee, though there will doubtless be further possibilities for longer term consideration when it reports. The operation and administration of the FOI Act is also currently under review by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. That wide-ranging review will doubtless encompass costs questions. Background Whilst the urgency of the current economic situation requires government action now, this does not preclude further consideration of the issues in the light of the reports of the interdepartmental Committee and the Senate Standing Committee. I shall briefly describe the main features of this Bill. Further details may be obtained from the explanatory memorandum. (Quorum formed) Application Fees The Bill proposes a $30 application fee for all requests. This will cover the cost of basic administrative procedures involved in processing the request. The existing $8 charge in respect of administrative procedures will be subsumed in this fee. It will be necessary to pay the fee when making a request. Until the fee is paid there will be no obligation on the agency to deal with the request. Processing Charges The existing charge of $12 per hour in respect of time spent searching for and retrieving documents is to be increased to $15 per hour. This increase takes some account of increases in wages and other costs since the charge was set in 1982. Where requested documents cover sensitive areas such as security, law enforcement, business, policy development and the like, it is often necessary for agencies to consult widely about possible implications of disclosure and to give very careful consideration to the consequences. This can be a costly process which must often be carried out by senior officers. It has accordingly been decided to introduce a new charge of $20 per hour in respect of the time spent determining what access can be granted to a document.

Speaker: Mr NA BROWN
Title: FREEDOM OF INFORMATION LAWS
text: What if they take all day to decide it?

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Title: FREEDOM OF INFORMATION LAWS
text: Well, that is $20 an hour. Internal Reviews Whilst internal review is certainly less costly than review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and is therefore a desirable intermediate stage, there is nothing in the existing charges structure to encourage an applicant to first consider whether he has been properly treated by the agency. He can always hope that review will result in release of more material, or in other favourable action, at no cost to himself. It is accordingly proposed that there be a $40 application fee for internal review of agency decisions. Personal Income Maintenance Documents No fees or charges will be payable by persons seeking access to their own personal income maintenance documents. The only exception will be where the person has already had access during the preceding three months and there has been no material change to the documents concerned. The existing provision for remission of charges provides that account must be taken of whether a request relates to a person's personal affairs, whether payments would cause hardship and whether disclosure of the documents is in the public interest. The last criterion has caused particular administrative difficulty. In practice many claims for remission on public interest grounds have been generated by members of parliament who have other effective means of access to government information or by media organisations operating on a commercial basis which are well able to make some contribution towards meeting the costs of processing their requests. It is proposed to remove this as a mandatory consideration in considering remission of charges. The existing remission provisions are not procedurally suited to dealing with remission of the new application fees. A new section will permit remission of an application fee on the limited grounds that payment would cause financial hardship and that the documents related to the applicant's personal affairs. 45-Day Time Limit As the Act stands at present the time limit for responding to requests would reduce to 30 days from I December 1986. Meeting this reduced time limit would require extra agency staff. It is proposed to maintain the present 45-day time limit. Refusal on Work Load Grounds Some requests have absorbed very large resources, adding up to many staff-months or even staff-years. Three difficulties have been encountered in applying the existing provisions in the Act enabling refusal of requests on work load grounds: First, only large requests directed towards classes of documents can be refused. Requests for large numbers of individually specified documents cannot be refused; Secondly, there is no simple test of what constitutes an unreasonable work load; and Thirdly, the tests take account only of time spent searching for and retrieving documents but not, generally speaking, time spent in consultation and deliberation regarding exempt content. The first difficulty will be met by extending the exemption to cover requests for large numbers of identified documents. As for the second Remission difficulty, whilst it would seem to involve a substantial diversion of resources in a large department to spend, say, more than five full staffdays processing a single request, such a diversion of resources could totally disrupt a small agency or office, particularly if it arose when staff were heavily pressed by other commitments. It is not therefore at this stage proposed to introduce an absolute limit on work load. The test will simply be whether the likely total work in dealing with the request would substantially divert the resources of the agency from its other operations; would interfere substantially with the performance by the Minister of the Minister's functions; or would result in substantial delays in dealing with other requests. The last point has been introduced as it would seem quite unfair that one person who made a large request should be able to hinder access to government information by other persons. The third difficulty will be met by providing that the total work shall be estimated having regard not only to the location and retrieval of relevant documents but also to the consultation and deliberation involved in deciding upon exempt matter. Publication of Information on Agencies At present agencies are required to publish separately statements concerning their organisation and functions. This results in significant duplication of material normally included in agency annual reports. The Bill proposes that the publications be amalgamated. The Act also requires publication in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette of an index of manuals, guidelines and other internal documents used by agencies in decision-making. There has been little evidence of public demand for such materials sufficient to justify printing and publication in bulk. The Bill proposes that copies of the index be available for inspection and purchase at the information access offices already established. This 'publication on demand' will avoid printing and publication costs without diminishing public access to the information. Agency Statistics I am currently required to report annually to Parliament on the operation of the Freedom of Information Act. A wide range of statistical information must be provided to my Department by agencies for this purpose at considerable cost. It is proposed to very much simplify this statistical information which must be reported. The Bill proposes a reduction to the minimum considered necessary for monitoring the general operation of the Act. Miscellaneous Amendments Apart from minor amendments consequential on the major changes described above, the Bill makes an amendment of section 45 to ensure that material provided in confidence to government by non-government sources will be protected even where the information has been incorporated in internal working documents. As the Health Insurance Commission now has certain functions in relation to investigation of Medicare fraud and overservicing it is no longer appropriate that the Commission should be totally exempt from the operation of the Act. Its transfer from Part I to Part II of the Schedule will provide that it is exempt only in relation to documents concerning its competitive commercial activities. Application The new fees and charges in the Bill will take effect only in respect of future applications and requests. Conclusion It is estimated that total revenue to be derived from the above measures will be about $4m per year. Additionally, the measures in relation to publication, statistics and burdensome requests will result in cost savings of about $4m. Together, the measures will reduce the net cost of the Freedom of Information Act by about $8m or 50 per cent. This is a significant contribution towards meeting the Government's budgetary objectives. Honourable members will note that these savings do not result from significantly reduced rights of access. The express exemption from fees and charges of persons seeking access to personal income maintenance documents will protect those who are most vulnerable in respect of access to information they need. The remission provisions will continue to protect other persons where hardship might otherwise prevent access to personal documents. In other cases requestors will make a contribution towards the costs of providing the benefit they receive. I commend the Bill to the House, I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill. text: I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. The Government will maintain the momentum of its policies, including the maintenance of growth, provision for disadvantaged groups, the development of stronger links with industry, and the maintenance of rational steady planning as the basis for decision making. Similarly, the overseas student charge applying to subsidised overseas students will be reduced by the amount of the administration charge. Speaker: Mr HURFORD
Title: OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE
text: Adelaide-Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer) (9.35)-I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. The purpose of this Bill is to make provision for the financing of the prospective Budget deficit in 1986-87 and in subsequent years together with the associated prospective deficits in the Consolidated Revenue Fund. Legally, payments from the Consolidated Revenue Fund cannot exceed moneys available to that Fund. In order to meet any prospective deficit in the Consolidated Revenue Fund it is customary to seek legislative authority to charge defence and other Consolidated Revenue Fund expenditure to, or reimburse the Consolidated Revenue Fund from, the Loan Fund. This Bill therefore seeks authority to borrow money for defence and other purposes and to enable certain other expenditures to be met from the Loan Fund rather than from the Consolidated Revenue Fund. I should make it clear, however, that the Bill does not authorise defence or other expenditures additional to those otherwise authorised by Parliament under annual Appropriation Acts and under Acts providing for special or standing appropriations. The Bill is simply a machinery financing measure-the provisions of the Bill in fact explicitly prohibit borrowings for expenditures additional to those authorised by the Parliament. Successive governments have, for many years, introduced legislation in the form of an annual Loan Bill to authorise the issue of moneys from the Loan Fund to meet defence expenditures or to reimburse the Consolidated Revenue Fund from Loan Fund in respect of certain non-defence expenditures. In view of the non-controversial, accounting nature of the legislation, which has been acknowledged by all the major political parties in the Parliament, the Bill has been drafted as standing rather than annual legislation. That is, the Bill would provide authority for the necessary financing measures for 1986-87 and subsequent financial years to the extent necessary in the light of the respective years' Budget deficits. Standing loan legislation will in no way detract from Parliament's ability to debate the Budget, nor, as I have already stated, does it impinge upon the Parliament's prerogative to authorise, and appropriate moneys for, expenditures for particular purposes. In the Budget Speech the Treasurer announced that the Budget deficit in prospect for 1986-87 is estimated to be some $3.5 billion. This gives rise to a prospective deficit in the Consolidated Revenue Fund of around $5.1 billion-the Consolidated Revenue Fund deficit can differ somewhat from the Budget deficit as some CRF expenditures and receipts are classified as financing transactions in the functional classification of Budget outlays and, for the purposes of the Budget figuring, certain Budget outlays are met direct from either the Loan Fund or the Trust Fund. Existing standing authorities enable some $2.5 billion of expenditure to be charged to Loan Fund in 1986-87, leaving a shortfall of some $2.6 billion for which separate funding authority is required. This Bill seeks authority to borrow moneys accordingly. The amount of borrowings that may be undertaken pursuant to the proposed legislation is, in the case of defence expenditure, the amount for which appropriation is sought for defence purposes in the Appropriation Bill (No. I)-some $7.2 billion in 198687-and any moneys for defence purposes that may be approved in subsequent appropriation Acts for a particular financial year. The effective limit in 1986-87 is likely to be significantly less than appropriations as defence expenditures cannot be charged to Loan Fund until the legislation is enacted. The legal limit for borrowing for non-defence purposes is determined by the level of borrowing authority approved by the Loan Council. It is estimated that the 1986-87 limits will be sufficient to enable the financing of the Budget deficit. In concluding, I emphasise that the Bill does not authorise expenditures in excess of those which have already been appropriated by the Parliament under Supply, appropriation or other Acts. It does not in any way impinge upon the Parliament's prerogative to appropriate public moneys but simply provides a mechanism for financing expenditures previously approved and appropriated by the Parliament. In commending the Bill to the House I table an explanatory memorandum related to the Bill. Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned. Title: OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE
text: Adelaide-Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer) (9.42)-I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. Earlier this evening the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced, as part of the 1986-87 Budget, a number of changes to the scope of the present wholesale sales tax system that are to operate from midnight tonight. This Bill, and two others I will introduce shortly, will amend the sales tax law to give effect to those changes. Given the comments already made by the Treasurer in his Budget Speech and the details contained in statement No. 4 of Budget Paper No. 1 and the explanatory memorandum being circulated to honourable members, I will do no more than outline briefly the changes proposed. Firstly, the rate of sales tax on alcoholic wine and cider and other similar fermented alcoholic beverages is to be increased from 10 per cent to 20 per cent. Secondly, certain presently exempt non-alcoholic beverages are to be taxed at the 10 per cent rate. These include packaged flavoured milk, non-alcoholic wine and cider and similar beverages and, broadly, all non-carbonated fruit juice products containing not less than 25 per cent by volume of Australian fruit juice. Another change concerns the rate of sales tax payable on luxury motor cars and station wagons, including four-wheel drive vehicles. Where the wholesale price for sales tax purposes of such vehicles exceeds $19,892, sales tax will be levied at the top rate of 30 per cent. The amount of $19,892 is the tax-exclusive wholesale price, on which sales tax is calculated, equivalent to a $29,646 retail price. This latter amount is the present upper cost limit on which depreciation is allowable on motor cars and station wagons for income tax purposes. This amount will be adjusted each 1 July in line with the indexation adjustment to the income tax depreciation limit. Finally, the Bill will correct a number of anomalies and inconsistencies in the various schedules to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act. The main changes are: Firstly, all swimming pools, spa pools, spa baths and hot tubs and accessories, which are currently exempt from tax or subject to tax at only 10 per cent, will become taxable at 20 per cent. Secondly, the tax payable on certain film and video recordings will increase from 10 per cent 1986 to 20 per cent. Thirdly, household fittings and sanitary ware will be subject to tax at the same rate as other household items, namely 10 per cent. Fourthly, the rate of tax on gardening and industrial hand tools and machinery for business or industrial use will be increased to 20 per cent. Next negatives, transparencies and film strips that are produced from exposed film, will be brought within the sales tax base, at the 20 per cent rate. Purchases of computers, calculators and other scientific equipment by individuals such as teachers, students and others for use in schools or universities will no longer be tax exempt. Such purchases by schools and universities themselves will remain exempt. All aircraft, including hot air balloons and other similar aircraft, are to be eligible for exemption from sales tax if used for business or industrial purposes. Finally, several exemption items will be amended to confirm the scope of exemptions currently reflected in decisions of the Commissioner of Taxation. I commend the Bill to the House. I table the explanatory memorandum. Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned. NA 1986 Bill presented by Mr Hurford, and read a first time. Second Reading

Title: SALES TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL
text: Adelaide-Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer) (9.47)-I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. The Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill will amend Sales Tax Assessment Acts (Nos 1 to 10) and the Sales Tax Regulations. The specific changes are as follows: The value of computer software has traditionally formed part of the Sales Tax base where its value has been reflected in the selling price of goods on which it is contained. However, in recent times those marketing such goods have, purportedly to protect copyright, used the technique of licensing the use of the software, thus separating its value for sales tax purposes from its carrying medium, for example, a disc or tape, which alone has minimal value. The Government could not stand idly by and allow this erosion of the sales tax base, nor permit its spread to other areas such as the marketing of sound recordings or videos. Measures in this Bill will ensure that the value of computer software, sounds or visual images when licensed separately from the carrying medium is brought back within the sales tax base. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has already indicated in his Budget Speech, in-house production of software will not be affected by these changes, nor will software produced for export. Software acquired as an aid-to-manufacture will also remain eligible for exemption. The Bill does not seek to tax the electronic transfer of software by means of the telephone system or satellite communications. The Government will, however, be giving further consideration to this question. The Bill will also change the sales tax ment of swimming pools that are constructed on site. In the past, their pools, which are at the top end of the market, were not subject to sales tax. From midnight tonight, the construction of the container or shell of such swimming pools will be treated as the manufacture of goods for sales tax purposes and subject to tax at the rate of 20 per cent. Until now the process of developing exposed photographic film did not constitute manufacture for sales tax purposes. This Bill will change that. The price charged for developing exposed film will be taxed at 20 per cent. Finally, the Bill will bring the Sales Tax Law into line with the Customs law, by ensuring that goods imported into Australia on a temporary basis may be entered for home consumption tax-free, where they will be for use in connection with an America's Cup yacht race in Australia or the Bicentennial celebrations. I commend the Bill to the House. Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned. NA Bill presented by Mr Hurford, and read a first time. Second Reading

Title: SALES TAX ACTS AMENDMENT BILL
text: Adelaide-Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister treat- Assisting the Treasurer) (9.51)-I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. This Bill will declare the rates of income tax payable by individuals and trustees generally for the 1986-87 financial year and for the 1987-88 and subsequent years. In so doing, the Bill will give effect to the significant personal tax cuts announced as part of the September 1985 tax reform package, and their introduction from 1 December 1986 as announced earlier tonight by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his Budget Speech. The tax cuts are to be reflected in lower pay as you earn deductions from 1 December 1986. Another tax reform measure to be implemented by this Bill will allow the tax-free threshold only on a pro rata basis in certain circumstances. The Bill will also declare the rates of income tax for 1986-87 payable on the 1985-86 incomes of companies, registered organisations and unit trusts treated as companies for tax purposes, as well as on the current year incomes of superannuation funds and certain other trusts. As announced in the September 1985 tax reform statement, the company tax rate is to be 1986 increased to 49 per cent in 1987-88 to help defray the cost of the new imputation system that is to apply from the commencement of that year. Legislation to declare that higher rate for 198788 and subsequent years, which will also be payable by trustees assessed in respect of trust income of non-resident company beneficiaries in 1986-87 and subsequent years, will be introduced later in these sittings. Accordingly, the rate of tax declared by this Bill for 1986-87 for companies and the other bodies taxed as companies will remain at 46 per cent. However, lower rates are to be declared by this Bill on the relevant income of some superannuation funds and on ineligible approved deposit funds as a consequence of the reductions in personal income tax rates. A further lowering of these rates, reflecting the second stage of the personal income tax cuts, will be contained in the later legislation to which I have just referred. I turn now in more detail to the personal income tax rate measures contained in this Bill. The personal income tax burden will be substantially reduced by an increase in the tax-free threshold from $4,595 to $5,100, and by a reduction of all marginal rates of tax, with major reductions in those rates applying at average and higher earnings. The reform of the rate scales will be in two stages. With effect from I December 1986 a five-step scale will apply and from I July 1987 this will reduce to a four-step scale. From 1 December 1986 the existing 25 per cent rate on income to $12,500 will be reduced to 24 per cent and the threshold level will increase to $12,600. The 30 per cent rate will reduce to 29 per cent and the next two rates of 46 per cent and 48 per cent will reduce to 43 per cent and 46 per cent respectively. There will be a significant drop in the highest marginal rate applied to incomes above $35,000 from 60 per cent to 55 per cent. From I July 1987 the marginal rates applying to income in the ranges $19,501 to $28,000 and $28,001 to $35,000 will both be reduced to 40 per cent, and the top marginal rate will drop from 55 per cent to 49 per cent. These changes to the rate scale will be reflected in the rates payable by non-residents. Because of the commencement date part-way into the 1986-87 financial year, the rate scale for that year is to be an average of the 1985-86 rate scale and the scale to apply from 1 December 1986-made up of five-twelfths of the 1985-86 scale and seven-twelfths of the new scale .. The average rate scale will mean a tax-free threshold of $4,890 for 1986-87 with the rate of tax on incomes to $12,500 being 24.42 per cent. A rate of 26.5 per cent will apply in the income range $12,501 to $12,600, 29.42 per cent in the range $12,601 to $19,500, while for taxable incomes in the range $19,501 to $28,000 and 428,001 to $35,000 the rates will be 44.25 per cent and 46.83 per cent respectively. The maximum marginal rate applying to income over $35,000 will be 57.08 per cent. An adjustment is to be made to the maximum rate of tax on the unearned income of minors for 1986-87 to reduce the 60 per cent rate now applying to income over $35,000 to 57.08 per cent. For 1987-88 and subsequent years a flat rate of 49 per cent will apply to all unearned income of minors, subject to shading-in arrangements for such income just over $416. The rate of tax on trustees assessed under section 99A of the Income Tax Assessment Act will be 57.08 per cent for 1986-87 and 49 per cent in 1987-88 and subsequent years. I referred earlier to the adjustment in certain circumstances of the level of the tax-free threshold. In 1986-87 and subsequent years, this threshold will be available only on a pro-rated basis in the year of income in which a person first ceases full time education at a school, college, university or similar institution. The adjusted threshold level will be the proportion of the full threshold that reflects the number of whole months in the year when the person was not engaged in full time education, including the month in which such education ceased. Where income is derived in the part of the year before the person ceases education, the adjusted threshold level will be increased by the lesser of the amount of that income or the balance of the full year threshold. The tax-free threshold will also be available only on a proportionate basis where a person becomes, or ceases to be, a resident of Australia in a year of income. This measure will not affect the present treatment of non-residents receiving Australian social security pensions and repatriation pensions that are taxable in Australia. The provisions of the bill are explained in detail in a memorandum, a copy of which I now table. I commend the Bill to the House. Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned. Title: MULTICULTURAL AFFAIRS REPEAL
text: I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. The purpose of this Bill is to repeal the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs Act 1979 and the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs Amendment Act 1985. The legislation will commence on a day to be proclaimed. Its effect will be to abolish the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs-AIMA. I remind honourable members of the communique of the National Economic Summit Conference in April 1983, which stated: . . . the future well-being of this country depends upon the acceptance of the cultural, social and economic implications of a multicultural Australia. That aspiration is an important objective of the Hawke Labor Government and our hopes were expressed during the debate last year about the proper role of AlMA. We believe that enormous improvements were made to AlMA over the ensuing year but not sufficient to avoid a further re-evaluation. The Review of Migrant and Multicultural Programs and Services, ROMAMPAS, under the chairmanship of Dr James Jupp, which has recently reported, has convinced us of the need for a range of approaches that will more effectively ensure that multicultural principles are accepted. In dealing with diversity, we must use diverse approaches to achieve acceptance of the values and benefits of our developing identity built on multiculturalism. Government must take direct responsibility for achieving objectives, and we believe we are now embarking on an improved strategy for that purpose. Part of our strategy involves the setting up of an office of multicultural and ethnic affairs to be staffed and funded within my portfolio in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The Government appreciates the contribution made by the Council and staff of the Institute to the cause of multiculturalism in our community. However, in our view the continuing life of AlMA is no longer the most effective means of achieving our objectives. The Institute will therefore be wound down and abolished before the end of this year at a saving of $1 m during 198687 and $2m in a full year. This Bill protects the Commonwealth's interests in that process. In commending the Bill to the House I table a copy BILL 1986 of the explanatory memorandum. Speaker: Mr BARRY JONES
Title: CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL
text: Lalor-Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce) (lO.10)I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No.2) 1986 which is now before the House proposes the removal of the 2 per cent revenue duty applicable to imports from general tariff sources under item 71.07 in Schedule 3 to the Customs Tariff Act 1982. This item covers gold, including platinum-plated gold, unwrought or semi-manufactured. The removal of the duty is to take effect on the third day after the legislation receives the royal assent. The main commodity involved in the removal of the revenue duty is gold bullion. It is accepted by the Government that the duty is impeding the development of the Australian gold market by restricting imports and preventing the necessary liquidity in periods of peak demand. The gold market could become in important source or foreign exchange earnings as an export oriented service industry. With the removal of the duty, Australia could become an attractive alternative for secure storage of gold bullion because of its geographical remoteness from Europe and political stability, thus earning foreign exchange from storage fees and commissions. The removal of the import duty should have no adverse effect on domestic producers. In accordance with the Government's commitment to simplification of the Customs tariff, the removal of the duty has been extended to the whole of the tariff item which includes gold bullion, rather than splitting the item to remove the duty from bullion alone. Financial Impact The removal of the duty from the relevant item is estimated to result in a loss to the revenue of the order of $20,000 per annum. I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill. Debate (on motion by Mr Tim Fischer) adjourned. NA

text: Lalor-Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce) (10.13)I move: Excise Tariff Proposals No.9 (1986), Customs Tariff Proposals No. 14 (1986) and Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Proposals No.1 (1986). Excise Tariff Proposals No.9 (1986), Customs Tariff Proposals No. 14 (1986) and Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Proposals No.1 (1986), which I have just tabled, introduce certain tariff changes in relation to manufactured tobacco, refined petroleum products and to uranium concentrate from the Alligator Rivers region in the Northern Territory. These changes give effect to measures contained in the 1986 Budget. These proposals are operative from 8 o'clock this evening by standard time in the Australian Capital Territory. Excise Tariff Proposals No.9 (1986) increase the rate of duty on manufactured tobacco and certain refined petroleum products for the purposes of the Excise Tariff Act.
